column1: <body>This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:

column2: • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
• What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
• What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
• How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?

column1: Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed.</body>

column1: In this short introduction course, you will learn which steps to take before you start writing. We will focus on the following questions: which journal is best for publishing my paper? How do you plan the writing process and find the adequate literature? Furthermore, we will be looking at the structure of an academic paper, typical academic language and reader friendliness.

The format of this course is a 3-hour workshop in which theory and practical exercises will be alternated. To wrap up, you will do a post-course assignment and get individual feedback on your writing.

column1: Economics typically assumes that people behave like ""Homo Economicus"". Homo Economicus is a rational and selfish person without cognitive limits. Psychology has shown that people do not behave like Homo Economicus. Consequently, economic and financial models can lead to the wrong predictions and policy recommendations. This course will give an overview of the limitations of traditional economic and financial models and how they can be improved upon by using psychological insights. The course will enable students to have a deeper and more critical look at their own profession and to learn how better economic and financial policy can be made.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students learn the basic assumptions about decision making that are traditionally made in economics.
• Students learn examples where these basic assumptions are violated.
• Students see a few examples of what these violations of traditional economics mean in terms of economic policy.
• Students learn the basic terminology used in economic experiments
• Students learn to recognise whether observed behaviour violates standard economic decision making models or not.
• Students learn to predict behaviour based on standard economic decision making models.
• Students get acquainted with economic experiments and the decisions to be made when designing such experiments.

column1: This course provides an introduction to statistics for medical research. Without focusing too much on the underlying mathematics, students will learn the most important concepts, statistical tests and software to be able to perform statistical analyses. Additionally, they will obtain skills to help them conduct responsible science and critically read study protocols and published papers.

This course is module I from the modules on statistics. It is a precursory course before the R course (module II), survival analysis course (module III) and the course on prediction models (module IV).
After completing of the course, the student should:

column2: • Understand the difference between descriptive and inferential statistics;
• Understand the basics of hypothesis testing and p-values;
• Be familiar with the most important statistical tests for comparing groups and regression analysis such as chi-square, t-test, linear and logistic regression;
• Understand the underlying assumptions and limitations of these techniques;
• Be able to perform basic statistical analysis in SPSS or R and interpret the results.

column1: Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

column1: This course introduces students to the field of business administration, the firm and its context.  As such, this course serves as introduction and background to your bachelor programme.  We do this by discussing three interrelated levels (1) the environmental level, (2) the organizational level (3), and the strategic level of the business context.

The context of firms has changed profoundly over the last years and decades. Technological developments, global integration, the global pandemic, climate change have changed the way we think about businesses and their behavior, and therefore calls for firms to reconsider their ways of organizing and strategizing.  This course offers an introduction to core topics, established theories and key concepts to help students not only understand the roots of business thinking but also be better able to navigate the current and future business landscape.

We begin by introducing the general framework of the course and present a brief history of business thinking. We then first zoom out to consider the environmental context of firms, focusing on current global trends and changes. We pay particular attention to the international context in terms of both the institutional and cultural frameworks in which firms do business.  Next, we consider the organizational context of firms, focusing on core features particularly in terms of how to organize businesses and people across borders. Finally, we consider the strategic context of firms, focusing on the competitive environment as well as the context in which management form and implement strategies. This strategizing occurs not only in the competitive environment but also in the broader societal context, which makes it important to consider also the ethics and corporate social responsibility of firms.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: At the end of this course students should be able to:

column2: • Discuss the main tenets and underlying assumptions of historical periods of management thought.
• Describe and discuss systems theory of organizations in their environment.
• Explain the drivers of globalization and its consequences for business and economies.
• Identify distinct economic, political and legal systems and how they affect the business context.
• Explain and compare the role of institutional frameworks in shaping a country`s business environment, and their effects on the way firms operate, including internationally.
• Recognize, understand, and explain the challenges associated with organizing, and organizing internationally in particular, in order to meet often conflicting demands.
• Understand the key people and roles of the upper echelons in the firm.
• Discuss basic concepts and different schools of thought in strategic management, including competitive, corporate and global strategy.
• Describe and compare various conceptions of business ethics and corporate social responsibility and illustrate ways in which the UN Sustainable Development Goals affect firm behavior.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116956,2023,Introduction to Commodity Trade and Supply Networks,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['RC Sluijk', 'WAA Jacobs']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Commodities are critical for the global economy as they literally power the world, feed the planet and provide the essential inputs in all the devices (e.g. smartphones) and household appliances (e.g. shampoo) that make our lives easy. Commodity trading involves the transformation of commodities in time (through storage), space (through shipping) and form (through processing). Commodity trading firms (CTFs) such as Vitol, Trafigura and Cargill are for a large part responsible for the supply and delivery of commodities to their clients, often large manufacturing firms, in which they take on (and offset) various forms of risks (e.g. price volatility, geopolitics, the weather, foreign currency exchange and operational risks such as delays in delivery) for their clients. Commodity trading thus involves highly dynamic information-intensive tasks and capabilities in the field of logistics, finance and technology.

The value of the world’s traded commodities is estimated to be around 6 trillion US$ annually. The way supply chains of physical commodities are managed by various trading firms and how these trading firms are capable of securing delivery to clients under volatile and risky conditions is the topic of the course. No better place to study this than in Rotterdam: Europe’s gateway for the global trade in physical commodities. Rotterdam forms the heart of the ARA-region (Amsterdam-Rotterdam-Antwerp), a global price reference point for crude oil and used as geographical benchmark in many commodity delivery contracts and freight prices. Commodity traders make use of the port to ship the commodities to markets and many have actual logistical assets (tank storage and warehouses) and processing operations (e.g. refineries) in the port in addition to the trade desks, supply chain support functions, head offices or holdings in the city.

The aim of the course is to introduce students to the world of physical commodity trading, explaining the mechanics of commodities trade (trading, risk management, finance, shipping) and the dynamics that shape the future of the industry.
Course attendance is mandatory. One can miss one lecture/question hour/case study per course after emailing a valid reason to sluijk@ese.eur.nl.
Missing more than one session without a valid reason will result in students not being eligible to participate in the assessment of the course.

• Comprehend the way commodity markets (physical and derivative) function and the role that commodity trading firms play in the worldwide physical delivery of commodities, including contracting, financing and shipping
• Comprehend the various forms of risks involved in commodity trading and how these can be mitigated

• Present analytical results to a professional audience

column1: Cultural policy could be defined as the intervention of governments for culture. One important form of government intervention is directly subsidizing art organisations and individual artists. However, government support does also take place through tax incentives, support to entrepreneurship, and the social security system.

In this introductory course, students will be acquainted with the major economic and sociological theories of cultural policy. In addition, students will be provided with substantial knowledge of the actual organisation of cultural policy in several European and non-European countries. During the weekly tutorials students work on preparing and presenting a case study on recent developments in cultural policy. Besides, students will discuss recent developments in cultural policy, on the basis of a paper that students write throughout the course.</body>

column1: Data science provides a new paradigm for the analysis of data. In this course, an introductory overview is given of data science. The main goal is to introduce several data science techniques. Amongst the techniques discussed are (penalized) linear and logistic regression including ridge, lasso, and elastic net regression, and principal components analysis. The techniques are categorized in supervised and unsupervised learning methods. Special attention is given to the bias-variance trade-off and penalty approaches that reduce the variance in prediction at the cost of some bias. The practical implication is to use cross validation to select optimal parameters with respect to predictive performance. The differences between statistical and computational approaches such as bootstrap and permutation testing for hypothesis testing are also discussed. Students apply the methods using the statistical language R in several group assignments.

column1: Business analytics and data science are becoming key drivers of competitive advantage. Only firms that can harness their data and develop strong analytic capabilities across all their business functions will be able to survive in fast-moving modern markets. In this course, students will take a first step in this direction, as they learn how to use Python to manage and analyse large data sets.

Coding is a key component of this course. Students need to be comfortable writing code by themselves. To be able to follow this course, students need to have sufficient prior coding experience (at least at the level of BIM Research Methods I).

column2: <title></title>

column1: Deep Learning represents one of the most exciting advances in machine learning with many ground-breaking applications being developed in recent years from areas such as image recognition, speech analysis, machine translation, and game-play. Underlying these advances are various types deep neural networks and although these can be very technical, in this course we will try to de-mystify them a little bit, so you will be better able to assess the possibilities and limitation in business practice. We will cover three main topics:

column2: <li>
Neural Networks
<li>
Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) (used particularly in text analysis and time series analysis)
<li>
Convolutional Neural Network (CNNs) (used particularly in image processing)

column1: The main focus of this course is practical and emphasizes learning-by-doing: you will be doing a lot of coding and go through the whole machine learning workflow in the main project from the real, practical problem cases. We put you in the role of the ‘analytics translator’: sufficiently grounded in both the technical aspects and the organizational aspects to be able to function as a bridge between the pure specialists in these areas, so that you will understand the technical, organizational, and ethical aspects of deep learning applications.

Overall course goal: at the end of this course, students should be able to apply a basic deep learning model to a practical decision problem and be able to explain the model and its results to relevant stakeholders, both technical and non-technical.
The course attendance for the workshops is not mandatory. However, attendance is to workshops is strongly advised for students, as the covered material is not included in the core text.

• Apply and Create the underlying principles of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) in a practical setting
• Apply and Create the underlying principles of Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) in a practical setting

• Understand and Analyze the components of a neural network model in a concrete example and evaluate its technical aspects as well as practical aspects/constraints such as data quality limitations, performance limitations and ethical considerations
• Discuss and Reflect business decisions into deep learning techniques and vice versa, and describe those decisions to technical and non-technical stakeholders.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/110660,2023,Introduction to Digitalisation in Work and Society,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['JMV Dingelstad', 'prof.dr. CL ter Hoeven']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Rapid advancements in technology, such as artificial intelligence, robotics, and algorithms, change the organization of work. For example, algorithms can reorganize work practices and knowledge sharing among employees, robotization can change relationships and work design, and platformisation can influence our perceptions of organizing and organizations. This raises questions on the individual, organizational, and societal level. In this course we will focus on these different levels of analysis and develop analytical skills and insights to understand the implications of taking one of these perspectives.

In class, we will first evaluate relevant theories to study work, organizations, and technology (e.g., technological framing, sociomateriality, and work design). Second, we will discuss scholarly work specifically dealing with technologies which have been at the forefront of the popular and academic imagination, such as robotics, algorithms, and artificial intelligence. Finally, we will discuss how taking one perspective (e.g., psychological, sociological and/or public administration) will shed light on particular issues and consequences, while possibly disregarding others. In doing so, we will move from subjects such as work design and automation to power relationships and algorithmic control in the context of the ‘gig economy’.

Students are encouraged to engage with the literature provided and exchange their perspectives on the literature bringing in their BA backgrounds and possible previous work experiences. Finally, through a multi-disciplinary group assignment at the Municipality of Rotterdam students will be invited to apply what they learned in practice, while an individual paper will provide room to develop personal ideas and critically reflect on a topic of choice.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will:
1. Be able to analyze how digital technologies might (re)shape the way we work, organize, and govern
2. Be able to reflect on technological change on the personal, organizational and societal level
3. Be familiar with different theoretical lenses to analyze work, organizations and technologies
4. Apply relevant theories related to organizations and technologies to real time situations and cases
5. Be able to critically reflect on different concerns and considerations related to technological innovations

column1: <body>This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:

column2: • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
• What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
• What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
• How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?

column1: Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The workhorse of econometrics is the linear regression model combined with Ordinary Least Squares (OLS). It allows researchers to investigate the relationship between two or more variables, controlling for other factors. For example, what is the effect of dividend announcements on stock market prices and investor behavior? Or which factors affect a firm's entry and exit into a market?

This course introduces linear regression, with particular emphasis on its use and interpretation. Attention is given to hypothesis testing, specification search, goodness-of-fit, model interpretation and comparison, and making predictions. Problems of multicollinearity, heteroskedasticity and autocorrelation are also addressed. Several illustrations will be discussed.
At the end of this course, participants should be able to estimate regression models using software like Eviews, SPSS or Stata, and to critically evaluate the results.

column1: In Introduction to Econometrics students will get acquainted with the toolbox for scientific economic research. The focus is on acquiring knowledge and skills useful for fundamental and applied research in both the public and the private sector. The complete cycle of scientific research will be discussed. Research design, conceptual thinking and cross-sectional and time series techniques will be discussed.

• Have tools to address violated assumptions of Ordinary Least Squares. The following topics will be covered: no simple random sampling, functional form, conditional independence (errors-in-variables, omitted variables bias, simultaneous equations bias, sample selection bias) and consistent standard errors.
• Can use common techniques and concepts for time series data such as dynamic models, stationarity, AR, unit roots and ARCH.
• Can apply all these methods using Stata software.

column1: In this course, we will deal with central economic concepts such as supply & demand, the market, elasticity, industry structures and production functions. The students learn to deal with these concepts and start applying them in their thinking on the cultural sector. We will deal with questions such as: how do markets work? How does demand respond to changes in price or quality of the product in question? How do firms achieve their goals subject to the market structure in which they operate? What are the limitations of economic theories? The course will consist of weekly, three-hour, interactive lectures.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In this course, students will familiarise themselves with basic economic concepts and how they relate to the cultural sector. After the course, successful students have sufficient knowledge and understanding of economic theory and the ability to address its uses and limitations in order to perform well during the Master of Cultural Economics and Entrepreneurship.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114601,2023,Introduction to Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['A Niutta', 'AC Crotta', 'B Daga, MA', 'dr. C Dalla Chiesa', 'LJLM De Strooper, MA', 'O Vincent']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This intensive course provides an introduction to economic theory and how it applies to the cultural sector, the arts and the creative industries. During eight weeks we will deal with essential economic concepts such as the market, supply & demand, elasticity, competition, monopoly, economic growth & development, entrepreneurship and copyright. The students learn to apply these concepts in weekly class-room assignments, and are introduced to their application to cultural sector and creative industries. We will deal with questions such as how do markets work? What is a rational choice? How does demand respond to changes in price or quality of the product? How does competition function in cultural markets? What causes economic  development and what is the role of culture in this process? What is the role of the cultural sector within the wider economy? Does the government have a role in (cultural) markets? What are the limitations of economic theories? What does thinking economically mean?</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The goal of this course is to familiarize students with economic theory especially micro-economic theory and how this applies to the cultural sector and the creative economy. After the course, the students should have a basic knowledge and understanding of economic theory, be able to make verbal and written economic arguments, and they should be able to apply these insights to analyze changes in the (cultural) economy.</body>

column1: <body>In this course, students will be made familiar with the context in which forensic and legal psychologists operate. Potential sources of bias in these areas will be discussed. The concept of criminal responsibility will be tackled.  Also, the likelihood ratio will be introduced. Students are made familiar with symptom validity testing, confession evidence, and dissociative disorders. At the end of this course, students will have a clear view of what forensic and legal psychology is.</body>

Become familiar with specific topics such as SVT, confession evidence, and dissociative disorders.</body>

column1: According to recent estimates, organizations lose about six percent of their revenues to dishonesty from within the firm. Such occupational frauds occur at various organizational levels – from the mailroom to the boardroom. While executives are “cooking” the company’s books to show better profits (e.g., Enron), purchasing agents are getting kickbacks from suppliers and employees embezzle money to improve their lifestyles. In this minor, we learn who commits fraud and why, what organizations can do to prevent and detect fraud, how affected organizations deal with crises caused by fraud, and how the legal system responds to fraud.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <div>After following this minor, students will be able to:
Understand the costs and personal consequences of fraud occurrences and how it affects individuals, consumers, organizations and society at large
Reproduce famous fraud schemes in history
Understand how pressures, opportunities, and attitudes (the “fraud triangle”) contribute to fraud and identify those
Define fraud and distinguish between different types of fraud
Recognize who commits fraud and why
Identify controls that prevent and detect fraudulent behavior, from the “tone at the top” to security measures on the shop floor
Analyze, present and discuss academic articles, which deal with fraud
Obtain a basic understanding of how the legal system deals with occurrences and risks of fraud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The course offers a general introduction to communication as a field of study and research. Communication is defined and described in detail by covering the basic processes involved (e.g. listening and attention, perceiving, using verbal and nonverbal communication). Next, the process of communication is presented in a variety of communication contexts (e.g., interpersonal, small group, public, organizational, intercultural). The course dedicates special attention to the context of media. The textbook provides a broad and accessible introduction to the field. The course material also includes academic articles in order to familiarize students with the products of scientific research. Course activities include, for example, discussion of key issues and questions, in-class exercises, presentations by students and discussions of student assignments. The classroom will be ‘flipped’ partially, by asking students to complete Socrative tests at home and during the lectures.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The nature and history of communication as a field of social scientific study.
• The basic theories and principles of communication and how these apply to different (professional) communication contexts across cultures.

column1: Students have the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Apply basic communication concepts and theories to different communication contexts.
• Analyze and reflect on the ways in which communication impacts their daily lives in multicultural societies.
• Present and communicate their findings and viewpoints in writing, oral presentation, and discussion.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course Introduction to Law provides a general, broad introduction to the law and to the study of law. Students will learn about the foundations of liberal-democratic legal systems, the basic legal concepts and the sources of law. They will become acquainted with the main legal families of law, namely civil law and common law; with the differences between private law and public law; as well as the fundamentals of main areas of law such as criminal law, constitutional law, and administrative law which will be studied from a comparative perspective. In addition to these substantive issues, students will also learn about the specific methods used by lawyers to solve legal problems and reflect on the forms of argumentation lawyers use to defend their case. With the help of literature and real life examples from case law, students will understand how lawyers use universal forms of reasoning such as deduction, as well as specific forms like legal analogy, and argumentation based on principles.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Describe and explain the main concepts of law, such as public and private law, substantive and procedural law;

• Describe, explain and critically evaluate the foundational concepts related to legitimate government;  specifically the ideals of a constitution, the rule of law, democracy, and the separation of powers;
• Describe and explain the theoretical foundations of legal procedures and gain a global insight in Alternative Dispute Resolution;
• Describe and explain the differences and convergences between civil law and common law;
• Describe, explain and critically evaluate the main principles of criminal law;
• Describe, explain and critically evaluate the main principles of contract law;
• Conduct a simple legal research on a selected issue and present your findings both orally and in writing;
• Argue in a case in a clear, structured and persuasive manner, both orally and in writing.

column1: This course provides a general introduction to the law and to the study of law. Students will become acquainted with the main fields of law: private law, criminal law, constitutional and administrative law. Specific attention will be paid to the basic differences between common law and civil law systems and to the relationship between national laws and European law. Besides the study and discussion of literature, students will train specific legal skills, such as the use of statutes, the analysis of judgments and the solution of legal cases. This course seeks to:
1. Harmonize levels of understanding of law among lawyers and economists in the EMLE programme;
2. Facilitate among lawyers from various countries an understanding of basic legal concepts and doctrines across legal systems;
3. Introduce both lawyers & economists to legal concepts and methods that are instrumental in the field of law and economics</body>

column1: The course is primarily theoretical. In this course we use a lot of linear algebra and see its connection with statistics. After the univariate statistics studied in the previous courses, we move to multivariate statistical methods. We start with the geometry of multivariate samples. Then we generalize the univariate methods to multivariate setting. And finally, we study several techniques that are useful in practice.
This course uses knowledge of FEB21023X Vector Calculus and FEB21007X(S) Statistics, and is required for FEB22004X Econometrics 1, FEB22017X Finance en FEB22018X Marketing.

• Students get introduced to the multivariate normal distribution.
• Students learn to apply some multivariate methods (estimation and tests) that involve the multivariate normal distribution.
• Students learn the basis of principal components and factor analysis.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112165,2023,Introduction to Port Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. B Kuipers', 'drs. M Jansen', 'MA Streng', 'prof.dr. AW Veenstra', 'WAA Jacobs']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: For economists, ports present a lot of interesting phenomena to analyze and understand. A port is a complex of functions, companies and organizations that plays an essential role in the national and global economy. A port is a part of our basic infrastructure, and a node in logistical and transport service networks. As such, ports are part of global maritime value chains. Ports are also locations for - clusters of - industrial and logistical activities. Here, ports are enablers for economic growth, innovation, and development. They enable trade, provide access to international markets for businesses located more inland and are – by themselves - clusters of economic activity generating added value and employment. In addition, ports generate substantial positive but also negative externalities. There are a number of different ways in which economists can look at ports:

column2: • What kind of economic activities are conducted in ports?
• What markets can be distinguished and what structure do they have?
• How is competition ensured or curtailed, either between ports, or between parties in the port?
• What determines the economic performance of ports and how can this be analysed and improved?
• What kind of economic subject is a ‘port authority’?
• What role do transaction costs play in understanding decisions made in a port?
• How do ports or industrial clusters develop and grown?
• How is an economic port cluster organized?
• Are there cluster advantages or disadvantages?

column1: These are questions that will be dealt with in this course. They revolve around the port as a node in transport networks, the governance of the port through a party like a port authority, and the port as an industrial cluster. For this purpose, we will rely on various relevant economic theories that can be applied to analyze and discuss these questions. In our analysis, we will primarily look at the port from an economic perspective, although some practical, technical, regulatory knowledge is also required.

The course consists of a set of logically structured lectures in which - based upon real cases provided by the lecturers - students will engage in discussions on the economics of ports. Part of the lectures will be used to play a serious game about some decision-making problem in the port. This game will be part of the assessment of the course.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• To understand a port as a complex of or location for economic activity, and as nodes in transport and logistics networks where economic principles as competition, pricing, agglomeration, transactions and market integration work in a specific way.
• To analyse ports and their challenges from an economic point of view
• To apply various economic theories and constructs to analyse problems and challenges in ports and develop rational economic choices and organizational solutions.

column1: The course starts by introducing the fundamental data types and operations. After that, control statements, i.e., decision and repetition, are presented. Then, methods, as computations consisting of multiple steps, are given. Lists and arrays, representing data structures storing multiple values, are depicted next. Last, the main concepts of object-oriented programming paradigm, i.e., class and instance, are described. The plan is to also make space in the course for recent developments in AI-assisted programming.

Meanwhile, students are expected to roll up their sleeves and acquire hands-on experience with the Java programming language. For this purpose, programming assignments will have to be completed by the students using a popular Integrated Development Environment (IDE). Students will develop an algorithmic way of thinking by implementing solutions for elementary computational problems in Econometrics.
This course is required for FEB22012X Programming, FEB22002X Combinatorial Optimalisation and FEB22006X Non-Linear Optimalisation.

• Be able to test whether the functionality of a program they implemented meets all the requirements.

• Be able to use AI-assisted programming tools.

column1: Most students are comfortable using commercially available software, like Excel or Adobe Photoshop. However, the power of being able to use computers expands dramatically when one learns how to think like a software engineer and how to design and even write one’s own computer programs. Programming, or “coding”, is an essential skill for a large number of academic and commercial activities. This course is an introduction to programming simple algorithms that can be extremely useful throughout anyone’s career. This course aims to provide students with an understanding of the role computation can play in solving problems. It also aims to help students, regardless of their future direction, to feel justifiably confident of their ability to write programs that allow them to accomplish useful goals. The course uses the Matlab (M) programming language, as it is easy to learn and useful in many scientific fields, and the acquired coding skills and the programmer’s mindset will be easily transferred to other programming languages.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
• Illustrate the value of computing and computer programming
• Become familiar with programming and the programming environment of MATLAB
• Apply the use of programming to a set of problems
• Learn how to continue learning how to program</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Coding is an essential skill for a large number of academic and commercial activities. This course introduces students to the programming language Python 3 (P). This language is widely used in academia, is open and free, and allows one to use a programming language used by a large worldwide community, as well as companies like Google, Facebook, Instagram, Spotify, Quora, Netflix, Dropbox & Reddit. Python 3 is well-supported and well-documented and allows for a number of things that other packages, e.g Matlab, do not. For example, like picking one’s own Integrated Development Environment. The course Computer Science M is not a prerequisite, but can be helpful because the way of thinking like a programmer is also taught in that course. Students will be offered lectures alongside tutorials during which they will work on exercises and assignments.

column1: <body>This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:

column2: • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
• What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
• What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
• How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?

column1: Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed.</body>

column1: The Refresher Statistics deals with elementary topics in statistics, which are taught in 4 sessions and assessed with a multiple-choice exam. The course addresses basic topics in statistics: summarizing data, probability, random variables, discrete and continuous probability distributions, sampling distributions, estimation and hypothesis testing. The aim of this refresher course is to ‘refresh’ statistical knowledge of students who have some background in statistics and to introduce basic statistical concepts to students who have limited or no knowledge about statistics

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114604,2023,Introduction to Social Science Methods,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['A Niutta', 'dr. MJ Berghman', 'E Aktug, MSc', 'EDAM Hermans, MA', 'GF Pires']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The contemporary debate about the cultural field (and society in general) relies very much on reliable and valid information. This course therefore addresses the basics of social scientific methodology – the way research is conducted to systematically gather information. In other words, this course is about the choices made and steps actually taken to get the necessary information. The course will address what social scientific research is about in general and situate the strategies available. It will introduce the main quality criteria for research. After that, it will focus on quantitative methodology in particular, discussing the underlying rationale, the main research designs, the selection of respondents as well as various methods (survey, content analysis, structured observation, …). This course is not just about the right way to do research – rather, it will mention the strengths and weaknesses of various options. Therefore, it is also very much about fostering a critical, but constructive attitude - students will learn to evaluate studies on their methods and suggest improvements. Moreover, they will gain experience with doing research themselves. They will develop a research question, derive suitable hypotheses and conduct a survey.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Students investing fully in this course will develop an understanding of the relevant concepts and main considerations when doing quantitative social scientific research. They will learn to identify the methodological choices made in actual research (whether of an academic or professional nature), evaluate those choices and suggest ways to improve studies methodologically.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114738,2023,Introduction to Social Science Research,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['BG Zerebecki, MSc', 'C Longas Luque, MSc', 'dr. CE Aalberts', 'dr. L Zheng', 'dr. RA Harder', 'ML Gaitan Aguilar, MA', 'prof.dr. MNM Verboord', 'TTV Nguyen, MSc', 'Z Hammana, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course familiarizes students to the theory and methods of social science research. Topics covered include the meaning of social science and empirical research; key concepts, rules and criteria in empirical research; main research designs and research methods in the social sciences; the role of selecting an appropriate research topic; reviewing and criticizing research; the role of theories and models in empirical research; formulating hypotheses; developing a research design and sampling plan; types of data and data collection techniques; data analysis; and technical writing. Students will be introduced to the entire process of conducting social scientific research and evaluating research conducted by others. Course activities involve library research, practical assignments that lead to the development of research evaluation skills, research skills and the writing of a research proposal, and participation in discussion groups.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The role, principles and key concepts of social-scientific research in relation to fundamental and applied social issues;
• The entire process involved in conducting social-scientific research;
• The main research designs, methods and techniques in social-scientific research;
• The basic principles of (internationally) comparative research.

column1: Students have developed the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Critically evaluate research reports and to draw theoretical and practical conclusions based on their review of the research literature on a particular issue;
• Develop a (basic) research design;
• Present their research reviews and research plans in a systematic and clear manner, both orally and in writing.

<body>This course introduces students to descriptive statistics aimed at ordering, summarizing and presenting quantitative data. Other topics covered include probability theory and significance testing, sampling, comparison of groups (t-test and analysis of variance), measurement of association and the detection and quantification of trends (regression). Course activities involve practical assignments that lead to the development of research evaluation skills, statistical data analysis skills, as well as proficiency in the use of SPSS. Students actively participate in discussion groups to practice statistical research skills.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Basic statistical concepts and methods commonly used in social-scientific research.
• Appreciate the role of statistical methods in research on arts and culture;
• Present quantitative data using appropriate displays, tabulations and summaries;
• Select and use appropriate statistical methods in the analysis of simple datasets;
• Understand and interpret output from statistical analyses;
• Present findings based on statistical analysis in a clear, concise and understandable manner;
• Evaluate basic forms of statistical data analysis reported in research articles and reports in the field of arts and culture studies;
• Apply the computer package SPSS for Windows/Mac.

column1: Statistics is concerned with drawing solid conclusions from available data. Following a brief introduction to the different phases of scientific research, the main focus of this introductory course is on developing the mathematical basis (probability calculus, probability distributions, introduction to statistical testing) and with applications in solving practical questions. The topics are the following:

Introduction to statistics, mean and standard deviation, empirical rule, theorem of Chebychev, axioms of (discrete) probability calculus, sets, computation rules, counting rules, permutations, combinations, conditional probability, Bayes' rule, discrete probability distributions, expected value, variance, binomial distribution, geometric and negative binomial distribution, multinomial distribution, Poisson distribution, moment generating functions, introduction to testing, null hypothesis and alternative hypothesis, significance level, power, P-value, testing with the binomial distribution, sign test, normal distribution, central limit theorem, computations with the normal distribution, z-test for 1 and 2 proportions, goodness of fit test, cross table, test on independence, chi-square distribution.
Some of these topics (such as testing and the normal distribution) will be treated more extensively in later courses.
This course uses knowledge of FEB21017X Introduction to Analysis, and is required for FEB21005X Probability Theory, FEB21007X Statistics and FEB21010X Mathematical Methods.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Understand the scientific role of statistics in applied economic research.
• Obtain knowledge of and proficiency in reasoning and calculating with probabilities, based on the axioms of probability theory.
• Obtain insight in the theory and application of some discrete probability distributions.
• Get experience in translating a (simple) research question into a (simple) statistical model.
• Get experience in (simple) practical applications and the interpretation of statistical results, including testing for categorical variables (comparison-of-means and cross tables).

column1: The course “Introduction to Strategy Economics” provides an introduction to strategic decisions of entrepreneurs and firms. Such strategic decisions include choices to enter and exit industries and to bring about change through growth and innovation. Throughout this course students are introduced to a selection of topics covered in the Master's specialisation Strategy Economics at Erasmus School of Economics of Erasmus University Rotterdam. The course “Introduction to Strategy Economics” covers the following main topics: 1) Entry and exit strategy; 2) Strategic policy making for firms and entrepreneurs; 3) Growth strategy; 4) Location strategy; 5) Industry life cycle strategies 6) Innovation strategy; 7) Human capital strategy; and 8) Global strategy.

column2: <title></title>

</style>
• Students can reproduce and interpret key concepts and theories in the area of entrepreneurship, (small) firm behavior and strategy.
• Students apply theories (such as on business closure and firm growth) to analyze (business) economic issues (such as real life examples of business closure and firm growth).
• Students present research results and policy recommendations on a topic in the area of entrepreneurship and strategy in written form.

column1: The aim of this course is to introduce the students to the societal issues that the SDGs tackle, the complexities of these issues and how these issues manifest themselves in our economic system. The course is divided in two parts. In week 1 to 5, the students will dive deeper into the societal issues behind the SDGs. After a first introduction, each week one of four themes will be discussed: a) climate change; b) immigration; c) social inequalities; d) healthy aging. For each theme, the following questions are answered:
1. What are the societal issues within the theme?
2. What are the main causes of these societal issues and how are they related to the characteristics of our economic system?
3. What are the economic consequences of these societal issues?
4. Why are these societal issues so complex to tackle? What are barriers in our economic system/thinking that hinder ‘solving’ these issues?
5. What economic policies are currently in place for these societal issues and why might they not be sufficient?

This introduction course is also the kick-off of the Impact Case assignment that will run during blocks 1, 2 and 3, and will be completed in the seminar of block 4. The Impact Case is a group assignment in which an external organization (case owner) will provide a student group with a question related to one of the four themes. The question will be related to a societal issue covered by the theme and for which the case owner wants to develop a policy plan. To introduce the Impact Cases and the case owners, each theme-week will close with a panel discussion including a short presentation by the case owner. At the end of week 5, the students are assigned to an Impact Case, taking into account the students’ preferences.
The education activities of this course are as follows.

column1: The course Introduction to Urban & Transport Economics is a Bachelor introductory course for the master specialisation Urban, Port and Transport Economics. At bachelor level, the course sets the stage and complements for an Urban Economics and Transport track.

Urban and transport economics has a long tradition as a discipline. All economic phenomena take place within geographical space. Traditionally spatial economic analysis has broadly been split into two sub-fields, namely urban economics and regional economics. These are by no means mutually exclusive categories and many analyses fall into both categories. The distinction between the two has arisen because of asking slightly different questions. Urban economics is generally concerned with the nature and workings of the economy of the city. Regional economics tends to ask questions related to the larger spatial areas than single cities, and the models used emphasize this broader spatial perspective, including commuting transport economics. However, there are many issues which can be analysed within either field, such as questions relating to the locations of cities, the location and performance of firms, the migration behaviour of labour, and the transport, storage and selling of goods and services.

Transport economics is a complementary well-developed discipline with branches in many areas of economic science. The transport sector can be divided into two large sub sectors: transportation of goods and passenger transport. Both sectors have witnessed dramatic changes in the last decades, especially in urban regions. On the one hand the increasing transport flows of goods around the world are the results of changing trade patterns and production systems and, on the other hand, the increasing predominance of private motor vehicle use in passenger transport is the results of welfare growth and changes in travel behaviour. Changing travel behaviour and changing appreciation of urban working and living areas together shape regional economic development potentials. This course focuses on the central question: how do we explain the interrelated development of urban and transport economic dynamics, and how do we satisfy the changing mobility and location needs of an increasing population in an equal, efficient and sustainable way?

Directions in which urban and transport economics developed in the last years are manifold. This is fuelled by the fact that the urban world is expanding at a rapid pace. Fuelled by social and economic networks, cities are becoming ever more central in modern society. The relation of urban economics and transport economics with other fields of research will be essential to understand the new realities and sustainable futures of urban (economic) life.

column1: • To get acquainted with basic theories on urban and regional economics and transport economics and learn more on the locational behaviour of people, companies and investors.
• To understand the observed patterns of geographical clustering of firms (for example Silicon Valley) and the economic explanations for this behaviour.
• To get insight in global location patterns and transport consequences of economic activities.
• To deepen the knowledge of the impact of fundamental trends as economic restructuring, globalisation, accessibility and the 'informationalisation' on the urban and regional economy.
• To understand the functioning of the urban and regional transport market.
• To increase insight into contemporary urban, regional and transport economic policy.

column1: Investor-State Arbitration is one of the key elements of the investment protection regime under international investment agreements (usually, bilateral investment treaties – ‘BIT’s). It is an exceptional dispute resolution mechanism allowing a private investor (be it as it may an individual or a corporation) to have a direct recourse against a (host) State in which it invested.

During the course the notion of investor and investment will be explained as well as different standards of protection offered under BITs. Further, the notion of the state’s consent to arbitrate will be discussed. Procedural aspects including i.a. taking of evidence and ascertaining applicable law, remedies, States’ defences as well as costs will also be analyzed. Finally, the course will cover what happens with the award at the post-award stage thus when it is challenged or when the enforcement of the award is sought.

Special focus will also be given to the developments currently taking place (i) on the European level (in particular in context of the intra-EU BITs) and (ii) in the UNCITRAL (which is working on how to reform the Investor-State dispute resolution system).</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>At the end of this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Evaluate the differences between definitions of investor and investment under applicable international investment agreements
• Evaluate the scope of an investor’s protection under different generations of BITs
• Reflect on the goals of respective investment treaties
• Evaluate when does the expropriation take place under the applicable BIT regime
• Review the scope of application of MFN and umbrella clauses
• Evaluate the scope of the applicable FET and FPS provisions
• Assess procedural preconditions for the arbitral tribunal’s jurisdiction (e.g. exhaustion of local remedies, fork-in-the-road clauses etc.)
• Differentiate between the burden of proof and standard of evidence
• Reflect on the law applicable to the dispute in investment treaty arbitration (application of international law and domestic law)
• Assess chances of successful application of provisional measures
• Evaluate defenses raised by Respondent States
• Detect remedies available for the investor
• Evaluate the fate of the (ICSID and non-ICSID) award at the post-award stage.
• Reflect on the future of investor-state dispute resolution mechanism

column1: The course deals with financial decision-making by investors and the determinants of stock and fixed income market prices. We will develop a critical understanding of key theories of asset pricing and portfolio allocation, review the latest empirical evidence, and discuss and discover the implications for real-world investing – including the advent of sustainable investing and attention to climate risks.

Financial markets serve many purposes in the economy. First, they allocate capital across economic investment opportunities. Second, they allow individuals to reallocate consumption across time by investing for the future at an appropriate expected return. Third, they allow investors to optimize their investment portfolios based on their preferences. Fourth, financial market prices serve as proxies for aggregate investor beliefs and thus convey important information to financial managers, investors, and policy-makers. Fifth, financial markets can play an important role in the transition to a more sustainable economy (i.e., sustainable finance).
The pricing of assets traded on financial markets plays a crucial role for each of these purposes. The goal of this course is to understand, apply, and evaluate theories, models, and evidence on what

determines the price of financial assets – and what this knowledge implies for investors. To that end, we will discuss the role and functioning of financial markets, the attributes of different financial securities, the preferences of investors, the fundamental principles of risk and return and diversification, portfolio theory and asset allocation, sustainable investing, the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM), the Arbitrage Pricing Theory (APT) and other multifactor asset pricing models, asset pricing anomalies, market efficiency, behavioral finance, and the limits to arbitrage. Furthermore, the course covers fixed income markets and the term structure of interest rates.

Understanding asset pricing is important for many practical applications. From the perspective of asset management (for example by hedge funds, mutual funds, and pension funds), an educated stance on what drives the prices of financial assets is crucial for investment and risk management decisions. Financial managers and decision makers at corporations rely on asset pricing models to estimate their cost of equity capital, a key input for capital budgeting decisions. Regulators and central banks need an understanding of asset prices to design policies to enhance the functioning of financial markets.
It is highly recommended to attend all course sessions.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Clarify how financial markets work and what their role is in the economy
• Analyze and evaluate stylized and real-life investment decisions based on advanced portfolio allocation and asset pricing models and tools
• Execute and interpret empirical asset pricing tests based on portfolio sorts and Fama-MacBeth regressions
• Assess the relation between sustainable investing (e.g., Environmental, Social & Governance – ESG – investing) and financial risk & return as well as impact
• Explain the central principles of bond pricing and the term structure of interest rates and analyze the role of interest rate risk in bond portfolio management
• Maintain a critical attitude regarding the limitations of our understanding of portfolio allocation and asset pricing

column1: The objective of this course is to help students bridge the gap between fundamental investment theories and modern investment practice.  We will consider empirical evidence for traditional theories and their implications for portfolio management.  This will involve mastering the tools of optimal portfolio construction and performance evaluation.  We will also learn about two key players in the investment management industry, mutual funds and hedge funds, and each topic will be put in the context of its use by both professional money managers and individual investors.  The course will include analysis of real financial data using statistical software and a group project to apply investment management concepts.

After completion of this course, students will have insights into the limitations of applying fundamental investment theories in practice, acquired skills for portfolio construction and evaluation, and improved their understanding of the investment management industry.

• Recognize the limitations of implementing traditional portfolio theories such as mean-variance investing
• Describe the professional money management industry and the potential pitfalls of delegated management
• Develop an investment strategy based on rigorous market analysis and fundamental investment principles
• Implement an investment strategy by constructing an investment portfolio that accounts for the institutional details of trading
• Analyze the performance of an investment portfolio to identify potential investment opportunities

column1: As future leaders in the business world, you need to understand what makes people tick. This course is intended to expose you to “behavioral” lens to understand why people make the decisions they do, and how to influence them for the better. Combining research from psychology and strategy with applications from business and the social sector, this boot camp practicum will teach you to influence people more authentically, communicate persuasively, and disagree more productively.  Armed with the behavioral lens, we will look “rationally” at the ways people behave “irrationally.” In doing so, you will develop and apply insights on how to employ behavioral science to address social and business problems of our time.
If you're unable to attend the majority of the course sessions, completing the assignments will be challenging, making it improbable for you to pass the course.

column2: • This course aims at targeting students who do not have a background in behavioral economics. If you have such a background, I advise you not to sign up for this course.
• This course may have some overlap with Dr. Hesam Fasaei’s Strategic Decision Making course. I advise you not to sign up for my course if you have taken that course.
• The information in this document is under regular reservation. When you sign up, please check Canvas for the most-up-to-date information.

• Understand the main concepts and theories related to irrationality in human decision-making
• Evaluate firm-level and institution-level policy designs by using the main concepts and theories that relate to irrationality in human decision-making
• Develop a toolkit of behavioral techniques that you can apply to win people to your way of thinking

column1: Islam is both a religion and a civilisation. This course argues that it is impossible to talk sensibly about religion without familiarising oneself with Islamic history. From its birth in the 7th century CE up until today, Islam has fascinated billions of people. To understand Islam in its contemporary forms and practices, one cannot but dive into its rich political history and its vast geographic scope. In fact, the ‘algorithm’, that very word so central to our digital age was first brought to us through the polymath al-Kwarizmi (800-847) who introduced algebra (al-jabr) into Western science.

This course combines history, politics and architecture as mutually complementary disciplines to gain a better understanding of Muslim actors, their ambitions and their terminology. Notions such 111 EUC Course Catalogue 2022-2023 May 2022 as caliphate (khilafa) and authority (sulta) as well as consultation (shura) or holy struggle (jihad) will be introduced and contextualised. At the same time, we must also look at how politics (both at local and global levels) have impacted the development of Islam and how forces like colonialism, capitalism or (neo)liberalism have defined Islam’s current status and perception.

NOTE: This course is a journey through Islamic history. It is NOT a course focused on contemporary Muslim politics, although that topic is addressed, among several others. Furthermore, this course does NOT follow the typical EUC format of problem-based learning tutorials. Rather, it adopts a student-led learning approach. This means that students should expect to prepare in-class presentations which, in addition to required readings, serve to structure our weekly seminars.

For a more general (PBL-structured) course on contemporary politics of Arab and Islamic states, please consider SBS314 Middle East Politics. For students aiming to take both SBS314 Middle East Politics and SBS316 Islam: A Political History, it is advisable to start with the latter one.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • distinguish main eras in Islamic history
• illustrate the geographic, ethnic and religious diversity within the realm of Islam
• identify key characteristics of Islamic architecture
• apply historic criticism on contemporary events/statements related to Islam

column1: Een cursus Italiaans bestaat uit tien wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 2,5 uur. Het afsluitende examen vindt na afloop van de cursus plaats op een vooraf vastgestelde datum (zie onderstaande planning). Aan het einde van de cursus is de stof van één cursusniveau behandeld.
Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Italiaans A1?

Tijdens deze cursus leer je de basis van de Italiaanse taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, schrijven en spreken in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

column2: • persoonlijke informatie vragen en geven (nationaliteit, beroep, talen & vrije tijd);
• groeten en afscheid nemen;
• tellen tot 100;
• spellen;
• de geleerde grammaticale kennis toepassen (o.a. lidwoorden, presente e passato prossimo indicativo van regelmatige en onregelmatige werkwoorden);
• vocabulaire;
• woorden zodanig uitspreken dat een native speaker hem begrijpt.

column2: <title></title>

column1: <body>Digital games are being played worldwide in platforms as diverse as consoles and mobile phones and hosted in the likes of Netflix and Steam. Furthermore, the tools for game-making enable game creation from the margins, with diverse developers creating and making their games available on itch.io, to also move to the centre of game production, distribution, and consumption. In this course, the goal is to ask and answer questions related to the digital games industry in one or more of three standpoints: production, content, and/or consumption. Working with close-reading methodology and textual analysis, students are encouraged to engage with analysis of in-depth gameplay data and the examination of game-related texts (e.g game reviews, game development postmortems, and video essays) to practice and experiment with distinct modes of qualitative research. Interviews, micro-ethnography and other qualitative methods are also welcomed. Students will conduct a small-scale research project in which (part) of the discussed theory is elaborated upon and empirically examined and will formulate a research question on topics that explore game studies vast interdisciplinarity.</body>

- Common research designs and methods to examine the subject of digital games
- Common difficulties and pitfalls of doing and reporting digital games’ research
- Design and execute a small scale empirical study
- Report on their findings in oral and written form
- Critically reflect on the limitations and implications of their research

column1: De cursus Japans voor beginners 1+2 is een dubbele cursus: aan het eind van het traject is de stof van twee cursusniveaus behandeld. De cursus bestaat dan ook uit 20 lessen van 2,5 uur. Voordeel is dat je tussendoor geen examen hoeft te doen. Je stroomt dus automatisch door van niveau beginners 1 naar niveau beginners 2.
Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Japans?
Tijdens deze cursus leer je de basis van de Japanse taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op luisteren en communicatie in een alledaagse context. We gebruiken het boek
‘ Marugoto’ . Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

column2: • jezelf voorstellen en persoonlijke voorkeuren vertellen
• Eten bestellen en winkelen
• Een afspraak maken en de tijd/kalender lezen
• De weg wijzen, uitleggen wat je hebt gedaan
• Japanse alfabet (46 hiragana, 46 katakana en ongeveer 60 kanji)
• Basis grammatica, woordenschat en uitdrukkingen
• Mondelinge communicatie en schrijf- en leesvaardigheden in het Japans
• Japanse cultuur en persoonlijke vaardigheden

column1: Tijdens de lessen word je geacht actief deel te nemen aan de conversatie- en mondelinge opdrachten. De ‘Marugoto’ methode wordt geleverd met gratis audio-en visueel materiaal op internet, waarmee je je luister- en spreekvaardigheid kunt ontwikkelen. De hoeveelheid grammatica die in het boek wordt behandeld, is minimaal. Je leert tevens hoe je een korte tekst moet schrijven.

Om het beste uit de lessen te halen, wordt er van je verwacht dat je elke week je huiswerk maakt en de woordenschat te oefenen. Houd er rekening mee dat het geen passieve lessen zijn, waarbij je alleen luistert, teksten leest en zinnen vertaalt.
Als je meer wilt weten over de ‘Marugoto’ methode, bezoek dan de website om het cursusmateriaal en inhoud te bekijken. www.marugoto.org
