column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115009,2023,Leading People, Teams, and Organisations for Excellence",Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. IJ Hoever', 'dr. M Meier-Barthold']",,"Inhoud

Organizations are complex social entities which are only successful if the people within them thrive and perform to their full potential. Leaders and managers play a critical role in helping individuals to reach this potential, to successfully collaborate to achieve a common purpose, and to leverage and respect the skills, insights, and experiences of a diverse range of employees. Fulfilling this role requires knowledge about how to shape behavior and promote performance in organizations and practical skills to implement them. Through this course, we will therefore explore the core question of how to encourage people to thrive and deliver excellence for organizations from three different angles. These angles are captured in three themes:

column2: <li>

Building successful teams: In the first theme, we focus on how individuals can productively collaborate in teams, which are a key building block of modern workplaces. Successful teams are critical for business success, but how can we help teams to function at their best?
<li>

Leading others: In the second theme, we focus on how leaders can motivate, direct, and influence the behavior of their followers. Leaders play a key role in helping employees realize their potential. At the same time leaders can be the source of demotivation and conflict. An understanding of how leadership can help people thrive and where it can go wrong is essential for effective organizational functioning.
<li>

Managing diversity in the workplace: The third theme puts the management of a diverse workforce center stage to explore how we can build organizations in which a variety of employees thrive and perform. Managing today’s increasingly diverse workforce presents organizations with a challenge that is both complex and potentially rewarding. This theme discusses key theories of diversity and offers insights into best practices in diversity management to help you realize the benefits and avoid the pitfalls of diversity.

column1: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

The central purpose of this course is to give students insights into critical questions regarding teamwork, leadership, and diversity management within organisations. Specifically, the course covers three broad learning goals (listed below). Each of these learning goals covers the three content areas of the course: building successful teams, leading others, and managing diversity.

column2: • Knowledge acquisition & comprehension: After following this course, students should be able to understand and explain the major theories about, and factors that contribute to effective team dynamics, leadership, and diversity management.

• Practical application & problem solving: After following this course, students should be able to use the aforementioned theories and research findings to critically analyse and solve practical problems concerning team dynamics, leadership, and diversity management. This involves the ability to:
<ul style=""list-style-type:circle"">

column3: • Select and find relevant theories and research findings for a given problem or challenge.
• Use these theories and research findings to understand the causes and contingencies of the problem or challenge.
• Develop recommendations and solutions based on the theory and the particular circumstances of the challenge or problem.

column2: • Self-insight & self-development: After following this course, students should be able to identify the strengths and weaknesses in their own functioning as team members and leaders in settings characterised by various levels of diversity. This involves the ability to:
<ul style=""list-style-type:circle"">

column3: • Reflect on one’s own behaviours, biases, and functioning.
• Develop concrete plans of how to further improve.
• Put these plans into action and reflect upon their success.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111095,2023,Learning analytics & the design of online learning,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. BB de Koning', 'dr. HK Tabbers', 'G Martins Van Jaarsveld']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: One fascinating aspect of online learning environments is that learners will leave digital traces of their behavior. On the individual level this raises ethical questions about privacy, and it requires rules and regulations to provide learners with control over which information will and will not be shared. On the group level however, anonymized trace data provide a rich source of information for all stakeholders involved in organizing, designing, and providing online education or training.

In this practical you will get hands-on experience in this field of ‘learner analytics’: the use of digital trace data for analyzing learners’ online behavior. We will especially focus on the role of learning analytics for evaluating and optimizing the design of a specific online learning environment. You will be provided with actual trace data from an existing learning environment, and you will not only be analyzing these data, but also you will also have to come up with a redesign plan based on this analysis.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Being able to analyze learner analytics data with the purpose of testing hypotheses on (un)intended learner behavior.
• Being Being able to translate these findings into a plan for redesign of the learning environment.

column1: In this minor, you will work as consultants to (Rotterdam and surrounding area based) social entrepreneurs and non-profit organizations. This course is intended to strengthen the skills and specific knowledge of students and provides a very practical experience. Instead of working with fictitious cases, you will be working with real, existing organizations. This will allow you to apply the knowledge that you have gained thus far to a real-life situation. In addition, the work you will be doing is intended to benefit both your client organization and the larger community. Interesting cases are pre-selected by the instructors, but we are open for any suggestions from students.

column2: <li>
become familiar with important issues and theories involving consultancy, social entrepreneurship, and the non-profit sector;
<li>
develop skills in the application of theoretical concepts to real-life situations;
<li>
gain experience with actual issues that arise in the course of a consultancy project;
<li>
be guided through: your first meeting with the client, how to write a consultancy contract and report, the actual process of consultancy, and how to present your recommendations to your client;
<li>
gain experience in finding, evaluating and applying relevant literature to the specific situation of a client organization;
<li>
develop and strengthen your creativity, teamwork, project, communication, research, writing, intervision, and presentation skills.

column1: <div>After the course you will be able to:

column2: • describe important issues and theories involving consultancy, social entrepreneurship, and the non-profit sector
• apply theoretical concepts to real-life situations

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115007,2023,Learning from big data,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. S Gabel', 'prof.dr. G Liberali']",,"Inhoud

Every day, millions of consumers voice their opinions in product-review websites, blogs, and chat rooms. They spontaneously produce massive amounts of user-generated content (UGC), most of which is textual and freely available for analysis. At the same time, online and offline retailers collect rich data sets that contain valuable information about the purchases of individual customers. In this era of big data, the availability of new, larger, and more diversified data sets creates exciting opportunities for marketing researchers and practitioners.

With so much data available, it can be hard to determine what information is correct or how to separate signal from noise. For example, how can you extract information about market structure and consumer preferences from purchase data? To make this even more difficult, UGC data are often unstructured and textual. Do you know how to analyze UGC data? And how do you go from insights to marketing decisions?

All that is needed to address these challenges is the right set of tools and the training that helps you to use the tools correctly. This course first teaches how to formalize marketing problems as statistical models. It then shows how to solve marketing problems by complementing classical econometric techniques with modern machine learning (ML) methods. You will find tools and conceptual frameworks needed to identify and exploit the opportunities that big data sources create.

The course has three modules, each containing lectures and hands-on activities. In the first module (“Mine your Own Business in Blogs, Reviews and Tweets”), we will work with various types of UGC, with a strong emphasis on textual data. We will discuss and use tools to help you automate the detection of both content and sentiment from texts produced by consumers. The second module (“Purchase Prediction with Boosted Trees”) focuses on the application of supervised ML methods to predictive and prescriptive marketing problems. The module also introduces important theoretical and practical principles for designing and implementing ML pipelines. In the third module (“Neural Networks–From Market Structure Analysis to Prescriptive Marketing”), we will use representation learning and deep learning techniques to model market structures in retailing applications and leverage insights for prescriptive marketing applications. There is one major “module assignment” to be handed in at the end of each module. In the assignments you will apply the methods, templates, and scripts seen during the lectures.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
Formulate marketing decisions as machine learning tasks.
Build well-structured and robust machine learning data/model pipelines.
Extract relevant insights on consumer preferences and behavior from user-generated content (UGC).
Analyze real-world loyalty card data to solve prescriptive marketing problems.
Collaborate efficiently when working on data science projects in teams.
Infer machine learning best practices from academic literature.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Course participants are introduced to the sources of the legal framework governing legal protection in the European Union with reference to the applicable legislative framework and case law. This covers mainly an analysis of:

column2: • The role of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) in the European integration process;
<li>The relationship between the Luxembourg courts (Court of Justice and the General Court) and the courts and tribunal of the Member States, including, among others:
<ul style=""list-style-type:circle"">

column3: • the relationship of the CJEU with the highest national (constitutional and/or supreme) courts;
• the limits of the application of national procedural rules.

column2: • The role of the CJEU and national courts in the rule of law crisis (with a particular focus on the rule of law decline in Poland and Hungary)
<li>The procedural rules applicable before the Court of Justice and the General Court, including inter alia:
<ul style=""list-style-type:circle"">
• The main legal action available before the Court of Justice and the General Court, including:
• Infringement action;
• Action for annulment;
• Action for failure to act;
• Non-contractual liability of the EU;
• Opinions on international agreements (including the Opinions on the EU’s accession to the ECHR).
• The main legal action originating in a national court of tribunal, including:
• Preliminary ruling procedure;
• Contractual liability of the EU;
• Liability of Member States for breaches of EU law.

column1: The overall grade is composed of a written assignment (in a form of a reasoned and informed viewpoint on a thought-provoking statement (‘hypothesis’) pertaining to the main topics of this course) and a final written exam. The written assignment counts towards 40% of the final mark, and the exam counts towards 60% of the final mark. The final exam is a 2.5-hour written examination, which takes place at the end of the course. It consists of two parts. The first part consists of short theoretical/essay-type of questions, whilst the second part consists of two short case studies.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The European Union is based on the rule of law. This requires an effective system of legal protection not only for Union institutions and Member States, but equally for the individuals (natural and legal persons). Central to the course Legal Protection in the European Union are the institutional and procedural aspects of the European Union framework of access to justice for the protection of the rights of natural and legal persons, of European institutions, bodies and offices, as well as of Member States, that they derive from EU law. Moreover, the role of domestic courts and tribunals in securing the Union’s rule of law is addressed.

In addition to the main lecturers of the course, several guest lectures will be provided by expert speakers who are active in legal practice. Participants will learn to understand and critically analyse the institutional and procedural aspects of the EU framework of legal protection and access to justice and the issues that arise in practice.
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

column2: • Independently describe, analyse and assess the main features of the EU system of legal protection and the role that the Luxembourg courts and national courts and tribunals play herein.

• Independently place issues relating to legal protection and access to justice in a broader legal context, by comparing them with national systems of legal protection and, even more broadly, the application of the rule of law.
• Independently apply the EU legal framework on legal protection in the assessment of legal disputes involving EU law before national courts and tribunals, as well as before the Luxembourg courts.

• Independently develop, conduct and account for academic research, and, based on this, provide a well-reasoned opinion of his/her own, as well as communicate, in written and oral format, pertinent legal advice.

column1: <body>Legal psychology aims to apply scientific psychological knowledge to the legal arena, particularly to criminal procedure. Hence, legal psychologists seek to study the behaviour of police, districts attorney, defence lawyer, judge, and jury. These parties may also ask legal psychologists explicitly for assistance. By and large, legal psychologists study the evidence used in court. In this course, various pieces of evidence, such as, witness statements including identifications, and suspect statements will be reviewed.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>The main goal of this course is to offer an introduction of legal psychology to the student. The following topics will be introduced during this course: Witness testimony, suspect testimony, lie detection. Besides these specific topics, it is important to gain insight in legal psychology as a discipline, and to appreciate the position of the psychologist in the criminal procedure.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: De minor is gericht op juristen, VMO-rechtenstudenten en staat ook open voor studenten fiscaal recht. In de minor maak je kennis met Legal Technology. Je leert Legal Technology begrijpen en gebruiken. Ook ontwikkel je een kritische houding vanuit een ethisch-juridisch kader. Daarmee kun je een bijdrage leveren aan de ontwikkeling en maatschappelijke en organisatorische inpassing van (Legal) Technology. We richten ons op juristen en fiscalisten die zichzelf zien acteren in traditionele (toga) beroepen, maar ook op de nieuwe juridische beroepen zoals: legal data-analyst en Legal Tech-developer.

Binnen de minor leer je te werken aan een oplossing van een real life vraagstuk dat ziet op access-to-justice voor de doelgroep de sociale advocatuur. De centrale ontwerpvraag die je krijgt is of dat doel bereikt kan worden met een Legal Technology én of dat deze tech-oplossing wenselijk is, gegeven de belangen van de doelgroep. Voorts leer je welke ethische aspecten hierbij komen kijken. Gaandeweg maak je kennis met de brede context van Legal Technology. Bij het ontwikkelen van de oplossing volg je een vorm van (Legal) Design Thinking. Het onderwijs vindt plaats via Expert Presentaties, werkcolleges en clinics. Er is een start- en een slotbijeenkomst met de stakeholders. Daarnaast zijn er momenten met externe partijen ingepland, zodat je jouw plan tegen hen kunt aanhouden. De clinics zijn gekoppeld aan de ontwerpfases van Design Thinking en bedoeld om vaardigheden op te doen die nodig zijn voor de ontwikkeling van de Legal Technology.

Je maakt kennis met kansrijke Legal Technology waarbij we specifieke aandacht geven aan verschillende AI-toepassingen, omdat uit die hoek de grote doorbraken worden verwacht in Legal Technology. Je leert de juridisch relevante werking van de technologie te begrijpen, als ook de grenzen en mogelijkheden van technologie.

In de minor vertrekken we vanuit het idee dat (Legal) Technology in staat is ethische en juridische uitgangspunten binnen het recht te transformeren. Technologie zet een nieuwe standaard voor ethiek, voor het recht maar ook voor traditionele werkwijzen binnen het recht. Het is een belangrijk onderdeel van de minor om studenten te laten reflecteren op de standaarden die (Legal) Technology zet zodat ze als jurist kunnen bijdragen aan een verantwoord gebruik, ontwikkeling en inpassing van (Legal) Technology. Ook zul je gaan ontdekken hoe Legal Technology jouw beroepsbeoefening zal transformeren en hoe jij daarop kunt anticiperen door nieuwe vaardigheden op te doen en traditionele vaardigheden te versterken.

Via engagerende onderwijsmethoden, schrijfopdrachten en interactieve clinics bereid jij je voor op de uiteindelijke opdracht die in de slotfase in groepen gerealiseerd moet worden. Die opdracht betreft de ontwikkeling van een oplossing die access-to-justice moet vergroten en/of borgen, eventueel via de ontwikkeling van een Legal Technology. Er is een slotbijeenkomst waarin het voorlopig ontwerp van de oplossing wordt gepresenteerd en een eindopdracht waarin na ontvangst van feedback van stakeholders (‘sluit de oplossing aan op de behoefte van de doelgroep?’) het definitief ontwerp wordt ingediend.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: De minor geeft studenten het technologische, ethische en juridische kader om als jurist relevant te blijven in relatie tot disruptieve technologische ontwikkelingen binnen het vakgebied van de jurist.

Leerdoel 1: De student kan na afloop van de minor verschillende toepassingen van Artificiële Intelligentie (AI) en andere kerntechnologieën zoals blockchain in de juridische beroepsuitoefening herkennen en de juridisch relevante werking daarvan beschrijven.

Leerdoel 2: De student kan na afloop van de minor identificeren wat de impact is van technologische ontwikkelingen en ontwerpoplossingen op fundamentele ethische en juridische uitgangspunten en hierop reflecteren.

Leerdoel 3: De student kan na afloop van de minor kritisch reflecteren op de positie van de jurist ten opzichte van disruptieve technologische ontwikkelingen en hoe deze de plaats van de jurist wijzigen [Wat is de eigen plaats van de jurist in relatie tot technologische ontwikkelingen in het werkveld van de jurist?].
Leerdoel 4: De student heeft na afloop van de minor inzicht in de effecten van verschillende technologische toepassingen op het professioneel handelen in diverse juridische subdisciplines.
Leerdoel 5: De student kan na afloop van de minor beschrijven op welke manier ethische en juridische uitgangspunten het ontwerp en inpassing van Legal Tech kunnen begeleiden.

Leerdoel 6: De student kan na afloop van de minor in samenwerking met anderen een reëel probleem ten aanzien van access-to-justice in kaart brengen en de mogelijke [technologische] oplossingen aandragen met behulp van een te volgen gestandaardiseerde methode [Design Thinking].
Leerdoel 7: De student kan na afloop van de minor actief participeren in de stappen voor het oplossen van vraagstukken in de minor: Analyseren, discussiëren en presenteren.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The aims of the course are to give students knowledge regarding core questions of contemporary legal theory and to help them develop their own critical perspective on the enterprise of law.

The students study central articles by contemporary legal theorists and examine their arguments together (i); students prepare assignments on set topics and debate about their arguments (ii); the exam will test students’ knowledge by setting problems, related to the literature, that allow students to show their argumentative skill as well (iii).

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After this course students are able to:
1.  analyze problems related to the concept of law from different perspectives and develop arguments based on different theories about the concept of law;
2. analyze theories of rights and the rule of law and apply these to moral and legal problems;
3. choose position on the basis of theoretical arguments with regard to moral and legal problems;
4. analyze legal interpretation, particularly in judicial opinions;
5. reflect critically upon theories of legal method;
6. write clear and well-argued statements on the issues under 1 to 5.

column1: The aim of the Life Support course is to give you a basic training in acute medicine and to experience ‘real’ working situations with help of some specially trained actors. The emphasis of the course is on the quick recognition of acute situations, clear communication, and adequate handling. We talk about how situations differ between inside and outside of the hospital, and between first-aid and professional medical care personnel.

During the course, the term ‘victim’ is frequently used. This term indicates a person who has an acute, (non-)life threatening disorder in her/his physical or mental health.  And who, in her/his own opinion or that of others, needs help. The common theme throughout the course is the ABCDE approach. This protocol is used internationally for the structured assessment and care of an acutely ill or wounded patient. In this course, the basic principles of this protocol will be taught. You will also learn e.g. how to assess the safety of a situation, call for help and perform CPR with or without the help an automated external defibrillator (AED).</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Following this programme, the student is able to:

column2: • Assess the vital functions according to the ABCDE protocol and provide adequate treatment to disorders of the vital functions;
• Carry out adequate resuscitation according to NRR guidelines when faced with circulatory arrest;
• Provide adequate First Aid to accident victims (including treatment of wounds and bites; bandaging; removing splinters).

column1: Literary movements and - styles do not emerge in a vacuum but are closely related to their proponent’s relation to the literary tradition, their reaction to their social context and their attitudes towards the future. There is, in other words, a politics of literature as much as a literature of politics. From the Romantic poet Percy Bysshe Shelly to contemporary hip-hop icon Kendrick Lamar, literary artists have been unambiguously preoccupied with questions of power, resistance and agency. Taking the emergence of ‘modern’ literature around 1800 as a starting point, this course will trace some of the relations between literature and politics up until the present. Rather than privileging one type of politics of literature over the other, students will engage with multifarious constellations of literature and politics through different theoretical orientations, historical contexts and literary genres. Each week will be centred around a particular theme (e.g. Literary Autonomy, The Politics of Literary Form, Literature and Community). We will read theoretical texts in conjunction with literary texts, from graphic novels to radical poetry and from feminist auto-fiction to utopian afrosci-fi. Ultimately, this course aims to provide students with the conceptual and analytical tools to reflect on and reimagine the possible relations between literature and politics.

column1: Whilst the 21st century has advanced our capabilities in many ways, that too brings with it many societal concerns, such as social inequality, immigration, global warming, and loneliness, to name a few. During this elective, students will explore societal issues of the 21st century and more importantly, collaborate with the goal of creating realistic and feasible solutions to prevent/alleviate these issues. Each group of students will be paired up with an academic supervisor to guide them along the way of contacting external stakeholders, analyzing the underlying mechanisms and reasons behind a societal challenge, measuring the effects of their proposed solution, presenting their findings and ‘giving back’ to the community in a way they see fit, based on the content of their project.

column2: • Given that you will be working with external stakeholders within the Rotterdam area, this elective is only for students who will be in the NL during the first semester.

• The groups will be designed in a way where we can best suit your area of interest. Once the elective registration deadline has passed, the coordinator will send you a survey to investigate what societal issues you are keen on focusing on. Groups will be formed based on the findings of the survey. It cannot be guaranteed that you will work on your desired project. But we will try our best.
• The goal is to have Dutch and International students working together on a project. Therefore, it is not possible you choose who you will be working with throughout the elective.

column1: Once weekly study skills sessions: You will cover various themes with the goal of developing your soft skills (e.g. time management, the writing process, group collaboration skills etc.). This session will be guided by the course coordinator.
Once weekly group work sessions: You will meet with your peers within your own team to discuss your POA, work on your proposal, end products and the process as a whole.
Once weekly check-ins with your academic supervisor (via online/in person – dependent on what you agree with him/her).

This elective deviates from the norm in that it starts during week 2 of block 2 (minor/exchange period) until the end of block 3. What is good to note is that it will require the same amount of hours as all other electives. The bulk of your work is expected during the elective period when you will carry out your project. However some prep work is involved before you begin (circa 12 hours throughout block 2 – brainstorming & writing your proposal).

NB: We will start with a brainstorm session, to be held on Tuesday October 24th  (15:30 – 18:00). During this session, groups will be formed and you will collaborate and decide on your proposed solution. This session is mandatory so it is important you ensure you are free at this time (i.e. it does not clash with your minor timetable).

column1: •    Students are able to explain the underlying mechanisms and reasons behind a global and/or local societal challenge that impacts members of a specific community.
•    Students are able to develop a strategy to prevent or alleviate the impact of this societal problem, through the integration of scientific and stakeholder knowledge.
•    Students are able to investigate the possible effects of their proposed solution.
•    Students are able to apply collaboration skills, in order to work together effectively in a diverse team.
•    Students are able to assess their personal-professional collaboration skills.

column1: During the Master’s program, students have the opportunity to explore a professional field of interest by means of a Research Internship. Arrangements have been made with around 15-20 national and international archives, museums, research institutes, educational organizations and business companies for research projects which students may select as the subject for their Master’s thesis. Please note that this is not a policy-related internship; it involves an academic research project. The final product may be a publication, an international workshop, website, object analysis or exhibition storyline. This research activity covers 18 working days (5 ECTS). Some internships are linked to the research of a master thesis.

All internships will be announced at the end of term-1 on Canvas; there is also an indication whether an internship is linked to a master thesis subject. The internships will also be presented at the Master Thesis Market.

Each student formulates a working plan after consultation with the faculty supervisor and the supervisor of the internship institution. Based on that working plan, an official Agreement Research Internship Master History of Society will be signed by: the student, the supervisor of the institution and the faculty supervisor. The research internship will be completed with a report, written by the student according to the guidelines of the master. The report contains also appendixes with important outcomes and products (written or images of the products). The whole report and internship will be assessed during a final interview with the supervisors. Based on this interview the supervisor of the institution will write a general assessment. The faculty supervisor will assess whether the student has reached the aims of this internship. For an explanation see the documents on the website http://www.eshcc.eur.nl/english/history/mahs/current/researchinternship/.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Mergers and Acquisitions are regular occurrences in the corporate world. Firms are acquiring other organizations for different strategic purposes: To diversify, to scale up, or to eliminate competition. They often present highly disruptive events for parties both within and outside the focal organizations. However, given their high degree of risk and complexity, mergers and acquisitions frequently fail to realize their intended objectives. In this course we review the most important research findings on M&A and discuss frameworks, theories, and case examples. We start by revisiting the foundations of corporate strategy and discuss the central but elusive role of synergies therein. We cover the decision-making stage related to buying and selling businesses and the implementation stage related to integration and separation. We focus on the different actors involved in these processes and examine their motives and constraints. We delve into the most frequent challenges and potential ways of mitigation. Adopting a behavioral lens, we focus on common biases, such as the overestimation of synergy potential and the underestimation of implementation complexity. We discuss the role of M&A in the long-term evolution of the corporate portfolio and the management of acquisition programs. We also zoom out to review the history of M&A and its impact on consumers and society at large. We explore the phenomenon of merger waves and bandwagon behavior, and examine the role of activist investors and private equity firms in connection with M&A.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Understand and apply the most important research findings on M&A and corporate strategy
• Analyze and evaluate the drivers and strategic motives underlying M&A decisions
• Analyze and evaluate the implementation challenges associated with M&A
• Analyze and evaluate the implications of M&A for different stakeholders

column1: Students that would like to gain some practical experience during the Master program, can do so by means of an internship. Students can use one of the elective blocks to do a full time internship.

Instead of an elective a so-called business project can be carried out. This business project will be shorter than a regular internship. The advantage is that such a project can be carried out during one of the three elective blocks. A student can come up with a business project at a company of his or her choice or can select a project offered by this master program. At the end of the internship the student will hand in a report (see Course Information).

The business project can be related to the thesis. However, this is not a requirement. Please not that even the two are linked, the business project will be assessed separately from the thesis itself and should contain another focus than the thesis. Please consult your thesis coach in case you want to combine your internship with you thesis.
THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR MI STUDENTS ONLY. IN OTHER WORDS: in order to graduate you MUST complete at least two MI programme electives!

In addition to the regular thesis work, the research project aims at acquiring more practical skills. Although such skills may differ among projects, in general the following skills may apply in the context of the company for which the project is carried out: Communication skills, teamwork skills, ability to adjust to company culture, ability to carry out a practical project under the supervision of a company manager.

column1: While traditional statistical and econometric methods often rely on strict model assumptions, methods from statistical learning and machine learning can provide more flexibility. Some of this flexibility is typically achieved through hyperparameters, which have to be tuned via validation procedures.

The main focus of this course is to develop a theoretical understanding of the discussed methodology. Students will gain deeper insights through mathematical exercises, as well as practical experience with applying the techniques in R or python through hands-on exercises.

column1: Machine learning is a key driver of the success of data-driven decision-making in business. It enables practitioners to learn from experience, as encoded in data, to understand business-relevant processes or to predict the future. It is an essential tool in the modern data scientist's toolbox.

This course provides a hands-on introduction to the concepts, principles and key algorithms for supervised and unsupervised machine learning. You will learn how these algorithms work and practice applying them to solve business problems. Attention will also be paid to principles, concepts and best practices which are required to apply these methods judiciously in practice, such as generalization, overfitting, resampling methods and evaluation metrics. The supervised and unsupervised machine learning algorithms covered will include decision trees, random forests, neural networks, cluster analysis and gradient boosting machines.

Machine Learning & Learning Algorithms is a core course in the MScBA Business Analytics & Management programme. It builds on knowledge obtained in the pre-modules and other core courses, with specific emphasis on statistics and programming. It provides knowledge and skills which will be leveraged to varying degrees by the elective courses.

</style>

column1: After taking this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Discuss key concepts and principles of machine learning, such as the data mining process, generalization, overfitting, model assessment methods and metrics, and the bias-variance trade-off
• Understand and compare several fundamental supervised and unsupervised machine learning algorithms
• Apply these machine learning algorithms to business problems and their accompanying data sets in a principled way using R
• Demonstrate critical thinking when assessing the merits of machine learning projects

column1: Instructors: Prof. Dr. P.J.F. Groenen (EUR), Dr. P. Schoonees (EUR).

Statistical learning methods arising from statistics, machine learning, and data science have become more widely available. These methods can be split into supervised learning, with the aim of predicting a response variable, and unsupervised learning, which aims to describe the relations between all variables simultaneously. This course focuses on particular supervised learning methods and has as its goal that the student obtains a thorough technical understanding of a selection of supervised machine learning techniques, can implement the technique in the high level language R and can write a report about an application of the technique. The follow-up course Machine Learning II covers additional supervised and unsupervised learning methods.

The book of Hastie, Tibshirani, and Friedman (2001, 1st edition) has been a milestone in connecting statistical ideas into machine learning techniques. Parts of the second edition of this book (2009) form the basis of this course. An overview of techniques and ideas to be treated are:
This course is a field course in the Tinbergen Institute program for 3 credits in the major econometrics.

column1: Prof. Dr. P.J.F. Groenen (EUR), dr. P.C. Schoonees (EUR)
Machine Learning II discusses supervised and unsupervised machine learning approaches which have become popular tools for solving practical problems.

It has as its goal that the student obtains a thorough technical understanding of a selection of supervised and unsupervised machine learning techniques, can implement the technique in the high level language R, and can write a report about an application of the technique. This course is a follow-up to Machine Learning I.

The first part of the course continues the discussion of supervised machine learning techniques from the Machine Learning I course. The second part focuses on unsupervised machine learning techniques for finding meaningful relations between all variables in a data set simultaneously. In contrast

to supervised machine learning, in unsupervised techniques all variables play similar roles. Therefore, the relationships among all variables must be modelled, whereas in supervised learning only the relationships between the target variable and the features are of direct interest. An important application of unsupervised learning techniques in management is customer segmentation in targeted marketing.
An overview of techniques and ideas to be treated are:
This course is a field course in the Tinbergen Institute program for 3 credits in the major econometrics.

column1: This course provides an introduction to machine learning techniques, focusing on those methods that are useful and popular in economic and financial applications. While traditional statistical and econometric methods often rely on strict model assumptions, methods from statistical learning and machine learning can provide more flexibility. This flexibility is achieved by a nonparametric nature of machine learning techniques, but also through so-called hyperparameters, which have to be tuned via validation procedures.

The focus of this course is to develop a theoretical understanding of the discussed methodology. In addition, possible applications in different fields of economics, finance, and operations research will be illustrated by discussing recent journal articles and working papers. Students will gain deeper insights through mathematical exercises, as well as practical experience with applying the techniques in R or Python through hands-on exercises.

column1: Instructors: Prof. Dr. E.C. Perotti (UvA), Prof. Dr. R. van der Ploeg (UvA)

The central bank’s mandate has grown in complexity, and has been refocused around its historical core task of financial stability. A central bank operates at the core of the payment system, serves as lender of last resort, conducts monetary policy, and is often the key prudential regulator.

Basel III has added a novel mandate to control endogenous risk creation over the credit cycle as the dominant macroprudential authority. This complex task requires monitoring systemic risk creation, balancing access to credit and financial stability. Understanding tasks in managing systemic liquidity and correlated risk-taking via macroprudential policy, requires an updated view of macro finance beyond the classic business cycle framing. The course focuses on novel insight since 2009 such as risk creation in a credit cycle, safety demand and challenges posed by structural change. Topics covered include good and bad credit booms, financial stagnation, central bank digital currencies and climate risk impact on financial stability.

The course is graded on a final paper and an eventual presentation. Attendance is strictly mandatory. The course would be ideally placed next to courses in macroeconomics, finance and banking by students interested in the big picture.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Learning goals for this course are:
Students should have an understanding of, ability to apply, judge, and communicate
1. Complexity of the Central Bank mandate including its function as lender of last resort, in monetary policy, and as key prudential regulator.
2. Concept of credit cycles as well as its empirical and theoretical implications and explanations.
3. Role global imbalances and demand for safety
4. Appropriate methodology to address questions in the field of macro finance
Knowledge and understanding: Understanding the literature on credit cycles, systemic risk creation and demand for safety.
Application of knowledge and understanding: Identifying relevant questions, well-grounded in the literature building on material covered in class.
Making judgements: Ability to systematize literature in the field as well as to point out gaps and potential conflicts.
Communication: Write a structured academic paper around a clearly defined question. Presentation to peers in the field.
Learning skills: Develop a research question that is well-grounded in the literature and systematically work on this question.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This elective course aims to broaden students’ perspectives and knowledge about Macroeconomics. Macroeconomic conditions not only affect us all in our daily lives, but business managers need to have a basic understanding of macroeconomics for a more comprehensive view of the market conditions, to be better equipped to respond to major macroeconomic events such as sudden increases in interest rates, or inflation, or even sudden resource scarcity (see the disruptions resulting from the war started by Russia in Ukraine). Incorporating a basic understanding of macroeconomic factors and how the economic environment affects the business, may give managers a significant competitive advantage by either helping them seize new opportunities or avoid costly errors. As individuals, we care about how inflation affects our abilities to pay for goods and services, how interest rates influence our access to financial resources, or how labor market conditions or technological developments affect our abilities to obtain specific jobs.

The range of topics covers the evolution of Macroeconomics and its theories, global instabilities, and their implications. This elective incorporates theory, practical applications, and economic puzzles, all relevant in a dynamic world. We start with identifying the primary schools of thought in the field, which is essential to anyone struggling to understand why macroeconomists so often issue divergent opinions on the same event (e.g., global economic crises). We then continue with an applied perspective on the classical key Macroeconomic indicators. Finally, some major global instabilities driven by political instabilities in critical world regions are reviewed. This course extends the knowledge gained during the first-year Economics course; it aims to give students a broader perspective on the wider environment in which companies develop and execute their strategies.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• B3EL105 Goal 1: Describe and compare the different schools of thought in Macroeconomics.
• B3EL105 Goal 2: Understand the dynamics of an economy
• B3EL105 Goal 3: Evaluate an economy’s state and recognize the potential for improving the country’s economic health.
• B3EL105 Goal 4: Assess the potential impact of macroeconomic factors/conditions/decisions on population approval ratings and implications for businesses.
• B3EL105 Goal 5: Critically assess the potential impact of unpredicted events (see covid-19) on economies’ health.
<title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Macroeconomics is the study of the economy as a whole, rather than of individual markets. It studies how aggregate-economy indicators, such as GDP, inflation and unemployment, behave, in particular how they react to economic shocks and policy decisions. Two areas of macroeconomics stand out: the study of the causes and consequences of short-run fluctuations in national income (the business cycle), and that of the determinants of long-run economic growth. In this course, we will develop simple macroeconomic models that allow us to analyse the behaviour of the main macroeconomic aggregates in the short, medium, and long run. We will see how these models and their predictions can be used to understand real-world debates.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, we will develop a simple macroeconomic model that allows us to analyse the evolution of the main macroeconomic aggregates in the short, medium and long run. We will also critically discuss policy debates, so that we directly observe how economic theory can be used to understand the real world.

column1: <div>This course introduces you to neoclassical growth models, and in doing so it serves as the link between the general equilibrium theory you studied in Microeconomics I and macroeconomics.

Neoclassical growth models are basic models of the evolution of aggregate economic activity over time which build on general equilibrium theory. Standard consumer and producer theory is used to model the behavior of households and firms. Markets are perfectly competitive and complete in these models, and typically bring about an efficient allocation of resources. In this sense there are no frictions or market failures. This class of models has served as a starting point for macroeconomists to think about a large variety of issues, including business cycles, growth, inequality, and asset pricing.

These models are useful for three related reasons. First, they are useful in understanding the efficient allocation of resources in a particular situation, which is a useful benchmark. Second, the nature of discrepancies between the efficient allocation of resources implied by the model and observations of what is going on in the real world can help to determine what type of frictions ought to be included in the model in the context of a particular application. Third, as one introduces frictions into the model to study a particular application, typically various elements of the neoclassical growth model are retained, so they remain important building blocks in the modeling toolbox of macroeconomists.

For example, so-called Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium (DSGE) models are a class of models that is widely used to study monetary and fiscal policy, and they are constructed by introducing a variety of frictions into basic neoclassical growth models.

The course starts where Microeconomics I left off. We continue the study of general equilibrium theory, with a focus on making it operational for analyzing the evolution of aggregate economic activity over time. Specifically, we will consider aggregation, dynamics, and uncertainty. Having covered these basics, we will study different versions of the neoclassical growth model, specifically a version with infinitely-lived households and a version with overlapping generations of finitely-lived households. To study quantitative implications one needs to solve the models numerically. As a first step in this direction, you will practice solving the neoclassical growth model using dynamic programming.

Similar to Microeconomics I, this is a first and foremost a theory course. We will use these models to take a first pass at some applications. The applications vary from year to year, and are drawn from business cycles, growth, inequality, and asset pricing. The purpose of the applications is primarily to promote the understanding of the theory, rather than provide state-of-the-art answers to applied questions.

column1: By the end of the course, students will be

column2: • Familiar with issues of aggregation, uncertainty and dynamics in general equilibrium theory
• Familiar with stochastic neoclassical growth models
• Able to numerically solve basic neoclassical growth models using dynamic programming

column1: The course builds on Macroeconomics I and applies dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models to the analysis of monetary and fiscal policy. It consists of four main parts. In the first part, we compare the inequality implications of a complete markets and a standard incomplete markets model when households face idiosyncratic income risk. Afterwards, we develop a basic competitive equilibrium framework which serves as the main building block for the course. The second part focuses on the role of fiscal policy. Here, effects of government spending, the role of public debt, and optimal taxation under commitment will be discussed. The third part introduces money into the framework and derives principles for optimal monetary policy under perfectly flexible prices. Further, the issues of monetary policy implementation and the determination of the price level will be addressed. The last part extends monetary policy analysis to the case where prices are imperfectly flexible. Within this framework optimal monetary policy under commitment and discretion will be examined.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
Learning goals for this course: students should have learned to
1. understand the link between insurance and individual consumption
2. solve dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models
3. show whether a long-run equilibrium exists and is unique, and derive conditions for a unique and stable set of policy functions
4. formally compute optimal tax and monetary policies in general equilibrium models
5. understand the economic mechanism why a certain policy is optimal</body>

column1: Instructors: Prof. Dr. E.J. Bartelsman (VU) and Prof. Dr. P. Gautier (VU)

Key macro indicators— unemployment, GDP, and productivity growth— may not follow the optimal paths determined in a frictionless economy. Recent models are much more careful in dealing with frictions agents face in reality, such as entry and exit fees, delays in finding transaction partners, information asymmetries, and limited contract enforcement. In this course, we explore the implications of heterogeneous agents facing various frictions that frustrate the allocation of resources in labor, capital and product markets.

By studying these models, students not only learn key aspects of three important topics in macroeconomics, namely labor market developments, business cycle analysis, and long-run growth, but also key building blocks that are useful by themselves.

We briefly discuss empirical regularities observed in the data regarding labor markets, firm demographics and productivity growth. After highlighting the difficulties of standard models to explain these regularities, we explore recent modifications. We start the labor market and discuss different ways to model how agents search, match, and bargain over prices. More specific examples are wage posting, Nash bargaining, and directed search. Next we turn to growth models of heterogeneous firms and study the implications of frictions for static and dynamic efficiency. Special attention will be paid to frictions in capital investment.

column1: Instructors: Dr X. Wang (VU) and Dr Y. Chen (EUR)

We draw on recent developments in microeconomic research on information asymmetries in financial markets and the consequences of market incompleteness to introduce financial frictions in macroeconomics. We pay special attention to the concepts of liquidity and financial fragility, to the consequences of limited risk sharing (market incompleteness), macroeconomic consequences of financial regulation and undercapitalized banks and to the macroeconomic causes and consequences of financial and Balance of Payment crises. Students will be introduced to many concepts from modern theories of financial intermediation and how they can shed light on the macroeconomic importance of financial structure.

column1: In this class, we investigate the making of traditions in both informal and formal settings. The focus will be on everyday material culture. Both in the academic field as in the wider heritage domain, there has been a growing interest in the culture of everyday life and ordinary things. Historians and ethnologists study the generational transmission and appropriation of repertoires of everyday culture, and many museums develop exhibitions on everyday practices, displaying ordinary objects. The findings of historical and ethnological research, exhibition projects and educational programmes will be confronted with each other and discussed in a broader cultural context, with the aim of coming to a better understanding of different forms of tradition making.

• Students can critically and analytically relate to academic and professional discourses on the dynamics of everyday culture
• Students can create their own vision on ethical and practical dilemma’s that heritage professionals are confronted with

Public Administration experts, both in science and practice, have to contribute to complex societal issues. The knowledge students got in the first two years of their bachelor program enables them to analyse these issues. This module offers them new theoretical, conceptual and practical knowledge and competences to formulate advices and design solutions, to bridge the gap between the current situation (“ist”) and the desired situation (“soll”). Core of the module ‘Organisation and Policy Consultancy” is to enhance these analytical, design-oriented and advising skills of students.

This module builds upon the theoretical approaches presented in the various modules on “Policy” and “Organisation and Management”. Students have to apply their knowledge in policy processes and public organisations, to analyse complex policy and organisational issues and to formulate solution-oriented advices. They develop a repertoire of skills for professional advising. In addition they learn how to assess whether the conditions for successful policy or organizational change are present.

• Describe current trends in management consultancy and policy advice in the public domain;
• Formulate the various steps in consultancy and advice processes and select suitable tools;
• Make a problem analysis / diagnosis of a complex policy or organisational issue;
• Design a policy advice or an organizational change intervention in a concrete case;
• Formulate a convincing, valid and practical usable policy advice or management recommendation;
• Reflect upon the relationship between clients and advisors and the mechanisms and values that constitute this relationship;
• Reflect upon the quality of advising in the public domain and its dark sides;
• Reflect upon the ethical dimensions of consultancy and policy advice;
• Formulate and assess the conditions for successful adoption and uptake of advices in the public domain.

column1: ​Management Control Systems (MCS) form the bridge between the organization’s strategy and its operations/services. Their purpose is to align managerial behaviour and decision making with organizational strategic goals. Although financial management tools are typically crucial  in an organization’s MCS, the design and use of a MCS does not only require an understanding of accounting techniques. It should also be based on a thorough understanding of how managerial behaviour is influenced by relevant control system elements, such as target setting, performance measurement and monetary incentives. Indeed, as the proper design of MCS is paramount for organizational performance, organizational failure can often be attributed to a poor design or implementation of the organization’s management control system. Past scandals such as the collapse of Enron and the recent crisis in the financial sector can be directly traced back to failures in MCS design. The emphasis of the course is on the analysis and understanding of the drivers of managerial (rational and irrational) decision making in complex organizations rather than on the application of accounting tools often associated with financial management.

The course strongly focuses on the managerial issues faced by CFOs of multinational companies. Meetings are case-based: students discuss (financial) management control topics in close relation to case studies of multinational companies. The assignments/tests will allow students to show their theoretical knowledge, but also their understanding of how to apply it to real-life case situations.

• Psychological and economic views on decision-making in contemporary organisations

column1: Management Control Systems form the bridge between the organization’s strategy and its operations. Their purpose is to align managerial behavior and decision making with organizational goals. Although management controls are typically embedded in the organization’s financial management and accounting systems, their design and use should be based on a thorough understanding of how managerial behavior is influenced by typical control system elements, such as organization design, target setting, performance measurement and rewarding.

Illustrations based on real-world cases are discussed, demonstrating when particular control systems are effective, and when they lead to dysfunctional managerial behavior. Indeed, while the proper design of management control systems is paramount for organizational performance, organizational failure can often be attributed to poor design of the organization’s management control system. Such poor design may result from a limited understanding of the drivers of managerial behavior in complex organizations. Our challenge thus lies in understanding what are crucial design elements of control systems, what design options are feasible, and how the design and use of control systems should match the organizational context in which they operate. This understanding, rather than the straightforward arithmetic often associated with accounting and financial management, forms the core of this course.

In that same spirit, management-control related ethical issues are considered. While control systems are generally intended to motivate desired behaviors, performance awards can also create pressure and temptation for employees and may cause them to step over the line between what they know to be “right” or “wrong”.  Those involved in designing and using control systems should therefore have a basic understanding of ethics.

Ample attention is also paid to contemporary organizational challenges associated with the broader corporate purpose of being a force for good in society. In light of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), we recognize how companies nowadays seek profitable growth, while being alert to their social and environmental duties. Specifically, companies can contribute to the SDGs by integrating these goals and key sustainability drivers into their strategy and business model. Since management control systems are an integral part of any organization’s pursuit of strategies, they can play a vital role in making the SDGs happen in practice. Throughout this course, we will see how companies can make SDGs a central element of the process of planning, budgeting, and performance measurement, and include sustainability targets and objectives in performance appraisal. The basic premise is that, if performance measurement and incentive systems are well-designed, they can effectively help organizations embed purpose into action as a path to achieve sustainable business performance and positive societal impact.

This course is intended to broaden and deepen your conceptual and technical understanding of accounting as it is used for management control purposes. The course demonstrates how to use control tools and techniques to effectively execute business strategy. You will also learn how to make business decisions, evaluate organizational performance, or evaluate others (and/or be evaluated) through the use of financial and nonfinancial information. These are essential skills for your future career, be it in the position of managers, management consultants, or specialists in staff functions such as controllers, auditors, or human resource specialists.
Although class attendance is not mandatory, it is recommended for all sessions.

column1: What does it mean to be a management scholar? Why do we do what we do? How can we do a better job? Many of us will strive to make contributions to both academia and society. The purpose of this course is to familiarize management PhD students with the rules of the game associated with our field, starting your transition to a management scholar. Fundamental to this journal is the ability to provide constructive and developmental feedback to others and to effectively leverage guidance from mentors, coauthors, supervisors, peers, and colleagues. In the short run, students will begin engaging with management literature, personalized histories of leading scholars, writing, and learning about the review process. The long run goal is to socialize students into management scholarship early and enhance students’ odds for success as a management scholar.

column2: <title></title>

column1: 1. Develop personal, professional development skills in writing and productivity standards, including setting reasonable goals and aspirations for research productivity. At the end of the course, you will have started the development of your basic skills in time management and basic “productivity” planning. These will be grounded in discussions around expectations on time demands in the PhD program and in your early career, and in a basic time-planning exercise.

2. Develop academic citizenship behaviors, including reviewing capabilities for top journals in their field and the ability to provide and utilize feedback and blind reviews. At the end of the course, you will be able to provide constructive comments to colleagues, write a basic review for an academic journal, and internalize comments from peers based on your writing. In addition, you will have a basic sense of how to discuss authorship on projects, what authorship ordering means, and how you might approach your journal strategy for submissions (in general) and your PhD program and early tenure.

3. Create original work that integrates leading scholarly thought into your own writing and research agenda. At the end of the course, you will be familiar with several of our most impactful management scholars. You will be exposed to both micro and macro scholarship, independent of your area of discipline, and you will attempt to integrate these essential scholars into your own interests (and research agenda).

4. Critically reflect on personal learning and growth. By the end of the course you will be able to constructively reflect on your work commitments, identify work-balance trends, set reasonable weekly-goals, and explore long term aspirations.

column1: Business analytics can be broadly categorized in three types. Descriptive/Diagnostic analytics which study data to gain insights about the current state of affairs, predictive analytics which focus on making predictions for the future or unknown events and prescriptive analytics which aim to utilize data and mathematical methods to make smarter decisions. This course is about prescriptive analytics. You will learn how to use management science tools and models to make informed decisions in a variety of business contexts. You will learn to represent the most critical aspects of a business case mathematically, that is, to build models that you can then use to analyze the problem and propose the best course of action. In doing so, you will understand that models are approximations, reflecting the most relevant, but not all, aspects of reality. You will learn to decouple the assumptions from the analysis and develop a well grounded appreciation for the value-adding potential of quantitative thinking but also the need to critically evaluate model outputs. You will get exposure to methodologies such as linear and integer programming, simulation, decision analysis and optimization under uncertainty and apply it to business cases from areas such as operations, transportation logistics and marketing. This is a hands on course and you will use Python and Gurobi to implement your models.

column1: The current challenges in media organizations and the media industry, such as the ongoing COVID-19 crisis, more generally a growing mediatization of organizations and society, rising competition, and an increasing complexity of organizational issues make managing and leading processes and practices of strategy and change highly relevant.

The course provides an overview of key theories and topics around strategy, management and leadership and works towards their reflective adaptation and implementation in media organizations and other mediated contexts. Students will comprehend and evaluate classical and modern approaches from managing change and strategy to competitive forces, industry analysis, resources and strategy processes and practices.

On this basis, we will discuss the possibilities of managing and leading individuals, teams and organizations through communication in strategic manner. Through diverse activities, students will apply these theories and approaches sensibly and creatively for learning how to develop successful actions in/for practice.

• Apply strategy and leadership approaches and theories reflectively;
• Lead social and organizational action through communication.

column1: This course teaches the fundamentals of managing, leading, and organizing in the media and creative industries and the strategic conduct of organizations that heavily rely on digitally mediated communication and distribution. Amidst fundamental changes in the media and creative industries, we will address, learn, and reflect upon the relevant management and leadership concepts and skills that current and future challenges require.

The course builds a social constructivist understanding of management and organizations, and a practice-theoretical view on strategy, leadership, change, and culture. It integrates both the managing of creativity, projects, innovation and technology, as well as dealing with transformation, uncertainty and risk. We will focus on a variety of industry contexts, such as for example digital gaming, film, music, publishing and streaming platforms.

The course is structured around (1) Theory & Expertise and (2) Transfer, Application and Reflection seminars. Through this structure we will reflectively integrate a variety of advanced discussions into industry and context-specific cases and challenges. Industry experts will share their insights on specific sub-sectors of the media & creative industries.</body>

column1: <body>By studying relevant literature on cultural heritage management, students will gain knowledge of the intertwining character of heritage, tourism, economy, culture and (local) identity. Subsequently they will be challenged to apply their theoretical knowledge to concrete case studies which will require them to carry out field work on location. The course will highlight the strategies that can be put in place to ensure the better preservation of cultural heritage while stimulating tourism. Literature discussions, interviews and field trips will provide a varied didactic program with a hands-on attitude.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The purpose of this course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills to apply their theoretical knowledge to concrete real-life cases. Students become familiar with the major trends and challenges in the world of cultural heritage management and how heritage management could go together with place-making and the creation of sustainable tourism. Moreover, students will gain knowledge of the experiences of various actors in the field of cultural heritage management and their insider’s view on current developments.

column1: This course will provide insights into the complex topics of diversity, equity, and inclusion in organizations and will examine how diversity can effectively be managed in organizations. At the end of the course, students understand the core diversity theories and empirical research insights, can critically evaluate the effects of diversity across individual, team, and organizational levels, and apply their learnings to real-world diversity challenges by identifying how human resource management (HRM) can contribute to the effective management of diversity in organizations.

Attendance is mandatory. In case the students are unable to attend a session, make sure to contact the lecturer in advance providing the reason for the students’ absence (e.g., job interview, sickness). Students missing more than one class will be excluded from further course participation. Due to the interactive nature of the course, it is not possible to attend sessions online.</body>

column1: Increasingly, in today’s fast paced, converging world, sustained innovation is a necessity not only to thrive but also to survive. However, for most firms, the strategies and processes associated with innovation remain vague and are not strategically managed. As a result, most firms are unable to innovate successfully, and thus fail to create meaningful value for their customers.

In this course, we will learn how firms could create and capture meaningful value for their customers. The aim of the course is to provide a set of concepts and theories as well as practical tools and processes that can be used by managers in their organizations to manage innovation more strategically.

In order to have interesting sessions and to benefit from them to the fullest, you need to come to the class and be well-prepared. Beside the fact that the nature of the course is intense and highly interactive, there has been always a very high positive correlation between active engagement in team assignment preparations and in-class discussions and debates on the one hand, and final performance in the individual assignment on the other hand. Therefore, ultimate attendance, preparation and engagement in all sessions and all aspects of this course are vital to have an enjoyable journey, benefit from the learning style of the course, and perform well in the course including the final individual assignment.

• Collaborate effectively in teams by connecting different perspectives to find solutions
• Communicate novel ideas and critical points effectively and convincingly
• Create solutions for societal problems by navigating complexity in the field of Managing Innovation Strategically

column1: In an age of rapidly evolving technology and international specialization, companies rely on mergers & acquisitions (M&A), joint ventures (JVs), and strategic alliances to innovate and tap into the technological knowledge of other companies. Yet, while these engagements become crucial supplements—or even alternatives—to traditional R&D, they carry inherent risks. In particular, companies face the risk of technology leakage through unintentional exposure of proprietary knowledge or, in more malicious cases, becoming victims of intentional espionage. Such leakages can erode a company's competitive advantage, lead to significant financial losses, and even pose broader geopolitical risks.

Against this backdrop, managing the transfer of technology and safeguarding intellectual property (IP) are critical for successful M&As, JVs, and alliances. Effective IP protection mechanisms are not just legal formalities but strategic management practices that safeguard core competencies, hinder reverse engineering, and prevent industrial espionage. Managers must learn to adeptly navigate the complexities of IP rights, international regulations, and cultural nuances to keep their businesses protected from potential exploitation and technology leakage while engaging in M&As, JVs, and alliances.

This course will equip students with insights how to effectively harness M&As and strategic partnerships for innovation while minimizing risks of technology leakage. Exploring real-world examples, such as the challenges faced by Apple in protecting its IP in China or Cisco's technology partnerships in India, this course not only offers theoretical insights but also prepares students for the practical challenges they'll encounter in the business world.
Attendance to all in-person sessions are mandatory.

column1: This course focuses on management in the context of interactive governance. Interactive forms of governance are on the rise in many countries due to several societal developments. They refer to processes in which multiple governmental and non-governmental actors interact in formulating or implementing public policy, services and decision-making. In addition to other courses in the Master programs, this course pays specific attention to both government-induced forms of interactive governance (citizen participation, public-private partnerships) and citizen-induced forms of interactive governance (community-based initiatives). The first means that governments organize citizen involvement in complex projects or initiate partnerships with private sector actors; the latter indicates that citizens and communities themselves show self-organizing capacity and initiative for the preparation, implementation and maintenance of public services in different sectors for example: sustainable energy, health and urban development.

Interactive forms of governance offer important potential for enhancing effectiveness, public support, empowerment and democratic quality of policy and decision-making processes, but are also challenging existing ways of working by governments and raise issues of accountability, inclusion and transparency. This course focuses on the potential and challenges of interactive governance and how specific management strategies and process designs could deal with these challenges and how they could enhance the democratic quality and effectiveness of interactive governance.

In a systematic way, the various conditions and barriers for effective and legitimate interactive governance are discussed. Secondly, relevant strategies, behavior and skills of managers are discussed to deal with these barriers. In this regard specific attention is paid to boundary spanning activities and skills in connecting governmental and non-governmental actors. Thirdly, a hands-on and reflective approach is taken. Students are challenged to critically reflect on cases and literature and to formulate practical advice to managers engaged in interactive governance.

Where characteristics and theories of policy and management issues have mainly been discussed at the meso and macro level in previous courses (in Block I), this course focuses specifically on the individual (micro-perspective): connecting and boundary spanning persons in interactive governance. The role of boundary spanners has already been shortly touched upon in the Policy innovation in Complex Systems course. This course takes a closer look at this and examines the barriers and management challenges faced by connecting persons within different forms of interactive governance. The skills, challenges and strategies of connecting persons as well as the effectiveness and legitimacy of their actions are central. The course includes several group assignments and a simulation game in which students learn to give substantiated and concrete advice to managers who deal with interactive governance processes.

column2: <title></title>
