column1: After completion of the course students are able to:
- understand the complexity and background of different forms of interactive governance;
- apply different perspectives on interactive governance;
- formulate critical conditions for effective and legitimate interactive governance
- explain the characteristics of boundary spanners and their role in managing interactive governance
- analyze barriers and management challenges of interactive governance
- formulate practical advice and guidelines for managers dealing with interactive governance processes and projects.

column1: Nowadays, in many countries the power of government is fading. Governments have failed to solve social issues and have diminished in scope. In addition, we do not only look to government anymore to solve the social issues of our time. Instead, a new type of party is playing an increasingly decisive role in the political and social arenas: non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

Indeed, the civil society sphere in which philanthropic, nongovernmental, and non-profit organizations are active is an often-forgotten societal actor, despite its importance. These organizations often focus on societal issues, such as combating poverty, reducing greenhouse gas emissions, saving the whales, advocating human rights or providing medical care for those who have little access to it. Many of them are focused on advocating governments and businesses to take their responsibilities. Others are collaborating with these organizations to gain additional resources. Just like business and governments, NPOs and NGOs operate in very diverse – or even more diverse – contexts. Furthermore, just like for-profit organization, NPOs and NGOs come in many different types, serve a mission, have particular strategies, and therefore need to be managed properly to achieve their goals. Yet this course shows that NPOs and NGOs are managed in a completely different way than the for-profit or governmental sector.

Though presence is not mandatory, we strongly advise you to be present if you want to pass this course. A streamlink can be provided when a legitimate reason is provided beforehand. Lectures are not recorded.

• Understand, analyse and evaluate the way in which the civil society sphere creates impact and interacts with and is related to the business and the governmental sphere

column1: This is a course on how to create, foster, and manage organizations in which people thrive and perform at their best. It proposes that (and provides evidence why) employee and group flourishing is key to organizational excellence in our quickly changing, complex, and ambiguous world. The challenge in managing from this perspective is how to architect contexts (e.g., jobs, organizational cultures, structures, and processes) that enable employees and groups to thrive? The challenge at a more personal level is how to find and/or create a context in which you yourself can thrive and manage at your best. The course will help students build organizations that are typified by virtuousness, meaningfulness, creativity, collaboration, and a focus on human well-being. Employees of such organizations experience trust, respect, high levels of positive energy, positive spirals of flourishing, and self-fulfillment.

column1: The Interim Project is a project-driven course in which students link their academic knowledge, acquired in previous years, to issues that currently exist in society and organizations.

The course is a B3 elective so you already studied the core disciplines of business administration. During the Interim Project (IP) you will be challenged to independently study a social theme/debate and make a practical contribution to the progress of this debate. This course focuses on the development of professional values and skills.

Three things make the course difficult and interesting at the same time. First, you are only given a global assignment. The theme group teacher presents a broad theme to you. Within this theme you define your own project together with your teammates. The other teams in the group will focus on other parts of the theme. Secondly, the assignment is about dealing with dilemmas. Dealing with dilemmas is the essence of the work of leaders. It is fundamentally different from problem solving. Finally, the Interim Project calls for creative teamwork. Together with your teammates, you investigate the theme and define a concrete project yourself. This requires consultation, testing ideas together, additional research and sometimes also redefining your own project or coordination with the other teams in your own theme group. This is therefore more than simply dividing the execution of the work.

The setup of the assignment is different from the assignments you have encountered in your study so far. You will be choosing and defining an interesting, relevant and workable assignment yourself within the theme of your group. The teachers will therefore act as coaches and leave the concretization, clarification, selection and demarcation of the assignment to the teams. This gives you freedom (but also the uncertainty and responsibility) that often characterize assignments in practice.

The general themes for this project have been developed by different RSM teachers and may vary each year. Each theme addresses current dilemmas from society and management practice. The themes confront students with complex, challenging topics where conflict, incompatible goals and ambiguity are inherent in the theme.

That is why the assignment does not consist of solving the problem, but rather of making a well-argued contribution to 'managing' (dealing with) the underlying dilemmas. Your project is therefore aimed at educating, developing and/or supporting the actors involved, rather than solving the problem yourself.

During the project you will work in a team (±5 students) which is part of a theme group (max 6 teams). Together with your theme group, you investigate a broad theme. With your team you define a concrete project within the framework of the theme. This gives you as a team the opportunity to choose a topic that appeals to you. This is an important choice that the team has to make. This choice cannot be made at once. Take your time for consultation, mutual testing of ideas, additional research and coordination with the other teams in the theme group and sometimes even redefining the project. That is why it is important to set aside sufficient time during the course for face-to-face consultation. Sharing, discussing and jointly interpreting information is of great importance for establishing and concretizing one's own project and speeding up the research process, especially in the first weeks of the project.

As a team, you must make a reasoned choice for a concrete, relevant and practically feasible project based on sufficient information. You then have to work this out. As a team and a theme group, you are responsible for managing and organizing your own team processes in order to achieve the end result. Teamwork skills are therefore important skills components in this profession that are given special attention.

At the end of this course, each theme group will present its teams' projects during a poster presentation at a market and in a one-and-a-half-hour presentation session. In case the situation doesn’t allow this we will ask for a video pitch. We will inform you on time about the form. Both are part of a concluding mini-conference where all groups present their work.

It is important that both activities are provided by the entire theme group and that it is presented as a whole. Each student team works to (1) clarify the diversity of views, interests and dilemmas of the parties involved in the subject and to (2) show how its own project helps the involved actors to deal constructively and effectively with their situation.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

</style>

column1: In the fast-paced, technology-driven world we live in, managing innovation has become increasingly challenging. The advent of Web3 technology has instigated a paradigm shift in the way we use, govern, and value the internet. Consequently, traditional innovation management strategies must adapt to this new era characterized by decentralized ownership, permissionless access, tokenization, and trustless mechanisms.

""Managing Innovation in the Web3 Era"" is a specialized elective course designed for MSc students at Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University. The course is structured to impart a profound understanding of the foundational principles, governance frameworks, and pioneering trends of Web3 technology. It aims to empower students with the essential knowledge and competencies required to proficiently steer and manage innovations in the fast-evolving Web3 environment.

The course is segmented into six distinctive modules, each focusing on varied aspects of Web3 technology: Introduction to Web3, Blockchain Governance, Fungible and Non-Fungible Tokens, Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs), Generative AI, and the Metaverse.

The course employs a mix of theoretical and practical learning approaches, including lectures, debates, workshops, and guest speakers, to foster a comprehensive understanding of the topics. Students are stimulated to participate in discussions and debates on provocative issues related to the future of the internet, promoting a culture of analytical thinking and inventive problem-solving.

The learning experience is augmented with cutting-edge resources, including a Notion database for exhaustive materials, HBR cases, and a dedicated Discord channel for seamless communication. A wide range of academic and practitioner readings is made accessible to students, allowing for a deep dive into the most recent advancements in the field.

Throughout the course, students are provided with opportunities to utilize their acquired knowledge through individual and group assignments, enabling them to exhibit their understanding and innovative capabilities in the Web3 domain.
As Web3 continues to transform the internet, the course is a crucial stepping stone for students aspiring to become the next generation of innovative leaders in this dynamic and evolving domain.
Attendance at lectures by guest speakers is mandatory.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Assess the core concepts of Web3 technology, including its underlying infrastructure, governance, and economic systems, emphasizing critical thinking and analysis (Bloom's: Analysis, Evaluation)

• Apply knowledge of blockchain governance, tokenization, and DAOs to real-world situations, exhibiting a deep understanding of their implications for collaboration, decision-making, and value creation (Bloom's: Application, Synthesis)
• Develop persuasive arguments in debates on controversial issues surrounding the internet's future, fostering effective communication and persuasion skills (Bloom's: Evaluation, Synthesis)
• Design a practical Web3 learning portfolio project, demonstrating creativity, innovation, and problem-solving skills in a real-world context (Bloom's: Application, Synthesis, Evaluation)

• Reflect on personal learning experiences throughout the course, integrating insights from academic and practitioner readings, class activities, and individual projects, to promote lifelong learning and personal growth (Bloom's: Analysis, Synthesis, Evaluation)

column1: Organisations are constantly faced with external pressures to change themselves – voiced by various stakeholders in their environment. Some pressures – so-called institutional pressures – will drive an organisation to become more similar to other organisations and adhere to established ways of doing things. Other pressures – competitive pressures – will instead drive an organisation to become more different from other organisations and develop new ways of doing things. And yet other pressures – normative pressures – will drive an organisation to take a stance with respect to ethical issues in society. Many change initiatives – such as total quality management, innovation management, M&A, sustainability standards, CSR programmes, and others – are the result of organizations attempting to manage these pressures from their environment.

How, under these conditions, should organizations develop and change? Doing so raises difficult questions for organizational leaders. How can their organisation walk the tightrope of adhering to established ways of doing things whilst also being distinct from competitors? How much should their organisation change to conform with its environment? And how much should it rather change in opposition to its environment? And how may it even become a force for change within its environment, changing not only itself but also other organisations? This course addresses these questions and in doing so develops a bird’s-eye-view of how organizations manage their environment by changing themselves – or not.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Explain how organisations are embedded in their environment and how external pressures for change are caused.
• Analyse different organisational strategies to manage the organisational environment.
• Critically evaluate organisations’ ability to respond positively to pressures for change and themselves become a force for positive change in society.
• Develop theoretically sound real-life recommendations for managing the organisational environment and responding to external pressures for change.

column1: This course focuses on the law and practice of marine insurance. Students learn about how ship-owners, charterers and cargo owners may obtain insurance cover against typical marine risks such as loss of or damage to ship’s hull and machinery, cargo damage and third-party liabilities. The course follows a theme-by-theme approach and draws comparisons between how these aspects are dealt with in case of a Hull & Machinery (H&M), a Protection & Indemnity (P&I) or a Marine Cargo insurance cover. The course adopts a comparative law perspective. Even though the starting point is the English Marine Insurance Act, this will be contrasted with provisions from civil law jurisdictions such as Title 7.17 of the Dutch Civil Code and from the Principles of European Insurance Contract Law (PEICL). Standard policy wordings such as the Institute Clauses and Club Rules are used as reference points where appropriate. The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases. Students need to prepare assignment that will be discussed during seminars. The course will be graded based on the assignments (20%) and a written essay exam (80%).

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: It is expected from students at the end of this course:
1- To understand the importance of marine insurance to shipowners, parties
interested in the cargo and third parties.
2- To  understand  the  different  types  of  coverage  available  and  the  main  types of marine insurance (cargo, hull and P&I) available.

3- To  be  familiar  with  the  roles  of  insurance  carriers  (corporate  insurers,  mutual insurance), insurance markets (e.g. Lloyds of London) and inter-mediaries/brokers and auxiliaries (classification societies, average adjust-ters and survey agents).
4- To  understand  basic  concepts  of  the  law  of  marine  insurance  such  as  causation, perils of the sea and the “pay to be paid”-rule.
5- To understand how P&I Clubs operate.
6- To  identify  the  different  and  at  times similar  approaches  taken by  English,  Dutch and Nordic Insurance Law

7- To be familiar with special features such as abandonment, putative risk and specific terminology such as barratry, frustration clause, waterborne clause, series clause, held covered, sistership clause, new for old, 3⁄4 running down clause, combined single limit, etc.).

8- To  be  able  to  identify of the sources of marine insurance law (not only the “hard law” (legislation), but also the “soft law” (standard conditions and model clauses used by the sector: “Institute Clauses” and “Club Rules”).
9- To be able to analyse and criticise case law on the topic.

column1: This course examines the complex legal relations and liabilities which arise when a ship at sea is in distress and/or suffers a maritime casualty. The course gives an overview of the many international legal instruments which (may) apply to various as-pects of a maritime casualty. It addresses the various mechanisms designed to pre-vent maritime casualties and marine pollution from occurring by raising the technical and safety standards of and on board of ships. These mechanisms include Flag- and Port-State Control, the Paris MoU and the role of Classification Societies.

Other subjects covered in depth include the law of Collision, Salvage, General Average, Limitation of Liability of the ship-owner, Civil Liability for Oil Pollution damage and Wreck Removal. The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases. The course will be examined on the basis of a written exam consisting of essay questions. Several lectures and/or workshops will be taught by guest lecturers from maritime practice.

column1: The main objective of this course is to develop a coherent framework for evaluating market risk at the levels of individual asset, portfolios of assets, banks and insurers and the systemic risk regarding the financial system and macro economy. The main tool that we exploit in devising this framework is the statistical theory about tail risk based on from Extreme Value Theory (EVT), in combination with standard concepts from finance and macroeconomics.

The course covers a range of methods for managing financial risk, with particular attention to downside risk measures such as Value-at-Risk (VaR), Expected Shortfall (ES), semi-variance, stress tests, and worst-case scenario analysis. We also study various statistical techniques for analyzing heavy-tailed distributions, including their convolution properties, and apply EVT to stress testing and scenario analysis. Furthermore, we explore the supervisory aspects of risk management, emphasizing the link between individual risk management and the stability of the financial system. We also discuss the fragility of the financial system and develop tools for measuring systemic stability.

Throughout the course, students will be required to submit empirical homework assignments and address theoretical questions. The rigorous treatment of some of the techniques will enable students to independently analyze market and systemic risk

</style>
• to identify the rigorous and quantitative techniques available in analyzing market and systemic risk
• to use various statistical techniques specifically designed to measure downside tail risk
• to identify and handle the additive properties of heavy tailed distributions both over time and in a cross section
• to select and use appropriate techniques to manage portfolio tail risk and evaluate systemic risk
• to develop indicators for evaluating the stability of the financial system.

column1: Knowledge and understanding: Students are required to carefully read the lecture notes and related research papers each week.

Application of knowledge and understanding: Students are asked to complete three assignments every two weeks. They assignment questions are related to the theory and methods discussed during the lectures. In addition, students need to conduct a computer assignment which requires applying the methods learned to a real data case.

Making judgments: Both activities (assignments and computer exercise) require critical assessments of which methods/knowledge to be used in solving the corresponding question. In addition, students need to write a research proposal as the take home exam. In the proposal, students need to decide which potential research directions can be relevant for the field studied and explore some novel ideas of their own.

Communication: Students must present the results of the computer assignment in a concise report, which can be potentially communicated to a chief risk officer. In addition, students need to present their research idea as a scientific research proposal, which can be potentially communicated with a committee deciding on the quality of the research proposal.

Learning skills: This course provides students a coherent framework for understanding and quantifying problems in risk management which pushes students towards research in this field. Students will gain skills for conducting research in this field after the course.

column1: In this course, the characteristics and management of markets are described in topics that include the marketing environment, components of the marketing mix, market segmentation, and planning. How do companies decide what products to sell or what services to provide? Is it important when the companies introduce the products/services into the marketplace? How do they know who will buy the product or use the service? What are some innovative new products/services that you think will experience growth in the next five years? What makes you think that these items will be successful? In completing this course you will explore some of the basic elements of marketing and answer these and other questions as you research and construct marketing functions as they apply to products/services currently on the market. The analytic part of the course moves from the general to the specific. The course is oriented around understanding the three C’s (customers, company and competitors), developing a strategy for the chosen product/market(s) and translating this strategy into more specific plans through the elements of the marketing mix, the four P’s (product offering, pricing, promotion and physical distribution).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course you will be able to:

column2: • Define the concept of marketing;
• Understand the fundamental principles of marketing, the key elements in developing and planning a marketing strategy, and the determinants of consumer behaviour;
• Master a set of analytical tools (i.e., frameworks, concepts, models, and techniques) for the evaluation and development of marketing efforts;
• Understand the practical relevance and use of the theory through exposure to examples of how companies organize their marketing efforts across a variety of business settings;
• Critically evaluate on organizational/ marketing problems by applying learned theories;
• Critically reflect on a number of ethical considerations raised by marketing practices and navigate ethical dilemmas in the marketplace.

column1: “Marketing Analytics” refers to a broad range of activities that rely on data to improve marketing decisions. This exciting field continues to grow in its scope and importance as the amount of data available to companies increases. Many large companies now have dedicated business analytics groups, and companies of all sizes are looking to hire marketing managers with a mix of technical and practical knowledge.

This course provides students with hands-on experience using many of the tools employed by marketing analysts. The purpose of this hands-on experience is not to develop students into analysts, but rather to help them understand the value and limits of these tools, and to develop the ability to communicate analytical insights to less technical stakeholders.

Attending live class sessions is expected, but attendance is not recorded and does not directly affect your grade calculation. Classes will not be recorded, unless the course changes to a purely online format.</body>

column1: <body>Marketing has become increasingly important as cultural and creative organizations and individuals need to become more engaged with their audiences. Organizations, artists and creative entrepreneurs compete to continuously justify their relevance, as they are challenged to generate more income from private sources such as (ticket) sales or sponsoring. They need to appeal to potential consumers by, for example, having a clear and appealing identity, communicating effectively, or bonding with their audiences. Thus, organizations in arts and culture need to prove their relevance time and again in a world where the preferences, expectations and needs of their current and potential audiences are shifting constantly. With the challenges and opportunities that technological advancements bring, marketing is an indispensable tool to shape meaningful relationships with diverse audiences.</body>

Students are expected to attend classes and participate when asked. During my lectures I will introduce the various topics and concepts that are core to this course. column1: Marketing strategy is a complex business function that requires a balance of analytical and synthetic skills. This course introduces a series of frameworks and tools that can be used to a) solve general business problems and b) develop specific marketing strategies and programs.

The analytic part of the course moves from the general to the specific. The course is oriented around understanding the three Cs (customers, company, and competitors), developing a strategy for the chosen product/market(s), and translating this strategy into more specific plans through the elements of the marketing mix, the four Ps (product offering, pricing, promotion, and physical distribution).

The synthesis of all these elements is achieved through case analysis. In addition to bringing together the different theoretical elements in the context of concrete business problems, active participation in case analyses will (1) allow students to enhance their problem-solving and decision-making abilities in various areas of marketing and (2) provide an opportunity to develop, present, and defend their own recommendations, and to examine and discuss the recommendations of others critically.

column1: Organisaties zijn zich in toenemende mate bewust van de noodzaak om waarde te creëren en klantgericht te werken. In een organisatie waarin waarde creatie voor klanten centraal staat, moet de strategie niet primair worden gebaseerd op producten of competenties, maar vooral op de drijvende krachten achter “Customer Value”. Het doel van deze cursus is om studenten kennis te laten maken met het marketingdomein. Belangrijke vragen die tijdens deze cursus aan bod komen zijn: ""Wat is marketing en het marketingconcept?"" en ""Hoe creëren bedrijven waarde?"" Waarde creatie, - communicatie, - levering en het te gelde maken van klantwaarde zijn centrale elementen in de cursus. Hierbij wordt veel aandacht besteed aan de invloed, uitdagingen en mogelijkheden die (informatie) technologie biedt voor het creëren van customer value.

column1: In today’s world oversupplied with media and entertainment content, the task of marketing movies, TV shows & channels, music, video games and comparable products is increasingly challenging. In a highly competitive environment, go-to-market strategies determine the product’s success or failure. In this course fundamental theories and perspectives on how entertainment is being marketed today are addressed.  Why and how is marketing media and entertainment products different to marketing products from any other sector? How is targeting fans different from reaching “traditional” target groups? These are central questions in the course. Furthermore, course topics include ‘positioning an entertainment property as a brand’, ‘building creative brand-centric strategies’, ‘creating products’ synergies’, ‘ecosystems and partnerships’, and ‘understanding how the digital world has impacted marketing and distribution’. The course allows students not only gain theoretical knowledge about the key aspects of leading strategic approaches, but also to learn how to translate them into actionable plans.

column1: Marketing is the interface between a firm and its environment. It is the managerial practice that ensures customer-oriented managerial actions, including product design,
pricing, market communication and product distribution, generate value for “customers”. The basic tenet is that managers should be able to justify that intended value-creation
actions lead to sufficient customer responses such that they surpass the costs of these actions. However, in practice, achieving such a goal is challenging, because of the sheer
number of uncontrollable factors that influence customer responses. To address these challenges, academics and practitioners have developed and adopted analytical tools in
the form of “marketing models,” which are crystallized from disciplines such as economics, statistics and computer science.

This course focuses on 1) how to translate managerial problems into analytical problems, and 2) how to solve these analytical problems with marketing models. In particular, the course covers important marketing problems, such as how to successfully design and diffuse a new product, how to price a product or service to gain short-term profits and long-term equity, and how to justify the costs of advertising. The course adopts a hands-on approach, where you are expected to work on cases with actual data to solve real managerial problems. Overall, the course will show you how to understand and influence customers using marketing models.
The design philosophy of this course is that marketing is an essential function for business operations. In line with this philosophy, we focus on models that originate from marketing.
Overall, we will cover the following models that center around “consumer value”:

column2: <tbody>
</tbody>

column1: Marketing with a data-driven approach has become the very definition of being a marketing professional. I will do my best to ensure you can benefit from the course, for both of your academic and professional development. The fundamental goal of this course is To help you make the transition to a data-savvy marketing professional.
To achieve this goal, the selected models in Table 1 are discussed in class and supported by cases with real data. Overall, the course encourages you to critically evaluate
marketing situations, select appropriate models, understand the applicability and limitations of the models, and solve marketing problems with the modeling results.
While many books or similar courses discuss different models separately, this course aims to unify the models with fundamental principles of marketing modeling. The
understanding of these fundamental principles enables you to critically evaluate different models and marketing situations. We will discuss the fundamental principles throughout
The attendance is not mandatory, but highly recommended.

column1: Individuals or households can choose to respond or not to a direct mailing, or they can choose between various brands in the supermarket. This course deals with econometric models for these qualitative variables. Examples of these models are the logit and probit models for binomial data and multinomial logit models for multinomial data. Also, ordered data, like those evolving from questionnaires, and count data will be considered.
The focus of the course is on model representation, model interpretation, parameter estimation and diagnostics.
This course uses knowledge of FEB22008 Markov Processes, FEB22005 Econometrics 2 and FEB22018(X) Marketing, and is required for FEB23021 Seminar Econometrics for Health and Society.

• Understand the statistical properties of marketing models.
• Translate the estimation results of marketing models into economically relevant information.
• Implement an econometric model using statistical software.
• Formulate the correct model to apply to a new marketing dataset.

column1: Marketing research is an essential component in present-day marketing and management. The cycle of research starts with formulating precise research questions, which can be translated into actual survey questions or data measurement. Issues that are addressed are:

column2: • Design of surveys
• Sampling
• Conjoint Analysis
• Segmentation using Cluster Analysis
• Pricing and promotions
• Relating quantitative results to the initial research questions

column1: There are two changes compared to the previous year. Both aim to make this course experience more applicable to the master's thesis writing.

1. The software used for the measurement tutorial is SPSS Process instead of SPSS AMOS. The reason for the replacement is that students can install Process free of cost, while it is not possible with AMOS, which requires students to work on campus.

2. Text mining (sentiment analysis) is introduced in the program, and a tutorial about this topic will replace the one using Qualtrics. This change will allow students to use unstructured data in their master's thesis.</body>

column1: The emphasis on this course is to use marketing research to aid to managerial decision making. Hence, we will focus our attention on the interpretation of statistical results in the applied aspects of various research techniques unique to marketing data. This is not a course on statistics and hence no attempt will be made to prove statistical theorems or derive mathematical solutions to statistical problems. However, this course builds heavily on prior knowledge on statistical methods and extends this to methods that are frequently used in marketing research. In particular, we will focus on ANOVA, linear regression models, choice models and factor analysis.

• Select the appropriate statistical method for a given marketing problem.
• Apply statistical methods to real-life datasets with the help of SPSS.
• Interpret the statistical output of your analyses.
• Recommend marketing actions based on your interpretation of the results.

column1: Marketing is a distinct research field with its own traditions and standards. It is typically divided into three interrelated sub fields; the areas of consumer behaviour, and marketing strategy and modelling.

The advanced seminars in Marketing discuss key insights and recent advances in these subfields to gain understanding of the current issues and research challenges. This course will draw exclusively on academic papers from leading journals and will feature interactive presentations by established senior faculty, as well as research presentations by up and coming junior School members. Participants are expected to actively participate in class discussions and to critically review and present assigned papers.
This topic is discussed based on recent insights taken from a number of recent papers from top journals in our field.
This session introduces the general field of marketing strategy and modelling, which uses insights from customer and market data, but also manager surveys to obtain insights.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Instructors: Prof. Dr. F. Sotgiu (VU) and Dr. J. Guyt (UvA)

Today’s complexity has pushed marketers and scholars to rethink the role of marketing. This calls for new tools needed to keep into account (dynamic) changes among the different players (from consumers to competitors) and across the various context (from environmental challenges to new channels).

In this course, we introduce seminal work in marketing, latest advancements, and modelling approaches. With marketing budgets under fire, companies demand marketing managers to act fast based on hard facts, to drive profitable growth and cut waste at the same time. Data overload, media fragmentation and multi-channel management have all complicated the challenge for marketers to prove and improve marketing performance. This calls for new tools needed to measure and evaluate the return on marketing investment.

These sessions will be instrumental in inspiring you towards new novel, relevant and impactful idea(s), but also in putting you in direct contact with some of the most successful thought leaders in Marketing Science today. To take full advantage from each session, read ahead the material and come prepared to discussed your own ideas.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Marketing strategy refers to the systematic planning of marketing activities aimed at achieving organizational goals. The ultimate purpose of marketing strategy is to develop and deploy an organization’s resources in the way that creates the most value for customers and other stakeholders.

Marketing is the interface between the firm and its environment. By providing the nexus between supply and demand, marketing activities play a fundamental role in the economic system. On the one hand, marketing activities (e.g., market research) ensure the allocation of company resources to the production of goods and services valuable to the selected target market. On the other hand, marketing activities (e.g., advertising) stimulate demand and, in turn, investment.

Studying marketing has never been so important or exciting. A number of trends will reshape business in the coming years. Key among them are (a) technology, especially Artificial Intelligence, and the coming of age of truly social media, and (b) the new sustainability imperative forced upon us by climate change. Business will need to become part of the solution, instead of being part of the problem. To succeed at this daunting challenge, businesses will need to update and in some cases fundamentally rethink their marketing strategy.

While these developments are new, fundamentally they are part of a pattern where change is constant, only the speed of the change is a variable. Historically, it has always been the case that success in business depends on managing change successfully – or at least more successfully than the competition. And over decades of research and development, many useful marketing strategy frameworks have been developed to aid firms in navigating changing markets.

Attending the lectures - and preparing them well - is absolutely vital to succeed in this course. Most lectures have mandatory readings. These are important to prepare the lecture, they do not serve as a summary of it. Especially the various cases are essential to read before the corresponding lecture takes place. During the lecture, we will discuss various aspects pertaining to the case. If you didn't prepare the case, you will be unable to participate in the discussion or appreciate the points being made. There will also regularly be a pre-class survey that checks your understanding of a few elements in the case and/or mandatory readings (see Course Assessment Plan).

column1: Almost two-thirds of senior marketers strongly agree that data-driven marketing is crucial to business successes within a hyper-competitive global economy, according to a recent study released by Forbes Insights (see https://trends.e-strategyblog.com/2016/02/23/how-marketers-use-data-driven-insights/26666). The proliferation of bigger, faster and better data has brought forth new opportunities, as well as unprecedented challenges. On the bright side, data analytics become the basis of strategic decision-making in almost all aspects of marketing. However, managers are being overwhelmed with an increasingly complex marketing analytic landscape. As of now, there are more than 9,932 marketing techniques available on the market (https://chiefmartec.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/martech-map-may-2022.jpg). Too many tools and too little guidance on when and how to use the tools create arguably the most important challenge for current marketing professionals.

Overall, the course is intended to make you well-informed and critical users of quantitative marketing tools. In particular, this course introduces a selection of quantitative marketing tools that are widely applied in marketing strategies. Through the discussion and application of these tools, the course will help you to 1) develop your ability of identifying and applying the right methods to marketing problems and 2) draw the right conclusions from the analysis. More-over, the course offers hands-on training in your competence in marketing analytics, including identifying opportunities of improving business performances with marketing analytics (""when to use"") and formulating an unbiased understanding of the output of analytical tools (""how to choose"").

Doing marketing with a data-driven approach has become the very definition of being a marketing professional. I will do my best to ensure you can benefit from the course, academically and professionally. The fundamental goal of this course is To help you make the transition to a data-savvy marketing professional, who knows the value of analytical tools and how to use them to guide marketing strategies. To achieve this goal, the course includes a comprehensive presentation of a selection of tools that are designed for various marketing strategies, such as pricing, targeting and positioning. These tools are discussed in class and supported by cases with real data. The instruction approach encourages you to critically evaluate marketing situations, to select the appropriate marketing tools, and to implement the tools. Moreover, this course aims to communicate the fundamental principles of marketing analytics. The understanding of these fundamental principles helps you critically evaluate new marketing tools in the future. The primary objectives of this course are:

column2: <li>
To help you understand the value and logic of data-driven marketing strategy.
<li>
To help you master a set of essential tools of marketing analytics.
<li>
To provide you with a framework to effectively understand and efficiently learn new analytical tools.

column1: Aside from these \formal"" objectives, this course is also designed to help you with the completion of your thesis, which is an integral part of our MSc program. As an instructor, I will try to get each and every one on board by focusing on the basics. However, if you want to learn more and challenge yourself, feel free to let me know.

column1: As future business leaders, strategy consultants or entrepreneurs, you will face challenging marketing problems every day.  Who are your main competitors?  Which customers are the right target group for your product?  How can you respond to market trends and changing customer needs?  How do you engage consumers in your shop and online?  And how can websites recommend news and videos to its visitors?  The marketing strategies you will implement can make the difference between success and failure, certainly for your products and maybe even for your whole firm.

In tackling the challenges mentioned above and building successful marketing strategies, many firms rely on big data and marketing analytics.  Indeed, in this age of data, successful managers must understand how big data and marketing analytics can inform marketing decisions.  Such tools have become a vital part of the skill sets of successful marketing professionals.

The objective of this course is to show you the benefits of using a systematic and analytical approach to marketing decision-making and get you familiar with the insights and methods you can use to understand marketing problems.  The course discusses important marketing problems and covers cutting-edge machine learning and data analytics techniques and data sets that should be part of the toolbox of modern data scientists.  You will learn how to pick the right solution for tackling analytics opportunities and challenges that exist in today’s big data era.  The course uses an action-oriented, applied approach to managing marketing problems with data-driven tools.  Example applications allow you to experience the value of quantitative methods in marketing even if you have little or no coding background.  After completing this course, you will be able to solve marketing analytics problems in a scientific and process-driven manner.

Attendance is mandatory for all sessions.  Two misses are free.  If you miss three or more classes every missed class will decrease your participation grade by 2 points.  Also note that the course’s group project starts after the second lecture.  The last hour of the first five lectures is dedicated to meeting with your group so you can work on the project.  If you miss any of these group work sessions, it is therefore very important that you talk to your group about how you can make up for your absence as soon as possible.  If you experience long-term personal circumstances which affect your study for a longer period (chronic illness, serious family circumstances, etc.), please contact the student adviser to discuss your study planning and progress.</body>

column1: In het huidige economische klimaat leidt de sterk toegenomen concurrentie ertoe dat veel bedrijven het moeilijk hebben om te overleven. Ondanks deze onzekere tijden, zijn er enkele bedrijven die er keer op keer in slagen om succesvolle producten te lanceren en hun marktaandeel op systematische wijze te vergroten. Dit doet natuurlijk de volgende vraag rijzen: welke factoren zorgen ervoor dat het ene bedrijf succesvoller is dan het andere? In het vak Marketing Management bekijken we een van de belangrijkste redenen: veel van deze succesvolle bedrijven hande-len namelijk vanuit een strategisch marketingperspectief. Door op systematische wijze in te spelen op de behoeften van klanten, presenteren zij een klantgericht producten- en dienstenaanbod dat duidelijk te onderscheiden is van de concurrentie.

In plaats van marketing louter te bekijken als de verkoop van bestaande producten en diensten, benadrukt dit vak hoe marketing management veelal een geïntegreerde strategie is waarbij de behoeften van de klant centraal staan. Daarvoor bekijken we hoe bedrijven de uiteenlopende behoeften van de klant kunnen analyseren en hoe ze op basis hiervan een strategie kunnen ontwikkelen waardoor ze zich kunnen onderscheiden van de concurrentie. Hierbij is het niet alleen van belang om goed uitgekiende producten en diensten te ontwikkelen, maar ook om doordachte beslissingen te nemen met betrekking tot distributiekanalen, prijs en promotiecampagnes.

column1: Na het met succes volgen van dit vak:

· Bent u in staat om te begrijpen en argumenteren hoe marketing een centraal deel is van de organisatiestra-tegie en hoe marketing een “force for positive change” kan zijn door het creëren van lange-termijn waarde voor klanten, bedrijven en de maatschappij in het algemeen;
· Hebt u een diepgaand begrip van de fundamentele principes binnen strategische marketing;
· Hebt u een diepgaand begrip van de centrale tactische elementen van marketing management;
· Bent u in staat om voorbeelden te geven van de gangbare marketing theorieën, onderzoeksmethoden en problemen in marketing management, en aanbevelingen te maken op basis van relevante literatuur.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: New products, which are also called innovations, provide new ways to create value for customers, and moreover, it yields growth and profitability for firms. A huge percentage of a company’s sales and profit is generally earned by products that have been launched in the past five years. However, at the same time, many new products fail, and disappear from the market sooner or later after its launch. This is very problematic for companies, given the huge amount of money involved in the research and development of new products. The success or failure of a new product is determined by its ultimate acceptance in the marketplace. This raises the question which factors influence the acceptance and diffusion of new products in the marketplace? This question will be central in this course. The answer to this question provides marketing managers with information on how to effectively develop and launch new products.

During this course the students get acquainted with both conceptual and tacit knowledge of important methods in launching new products, and moreover in tracking the new product launch. Additionally, this course will provide a structured overview of the body of knowledge on adoption (or rejection) and diffusion of new products in the marketplace, and moreover, insights into how this knowledge can be incorporated in new product launch decisions. Attention will be paid to the consumer adoption decision process as well as to the new product adoption decisions by retailers, both in the domestic and the international market. The course challenges you to think critically about new products marketing. As such, routine learning of terms and concepts is not enough, you should also develop skills to evaluate a new product’s potential in the market, being able to select the best new product launch strategy, and subsequently analyze and evaluate the success of the new product in the market.

Being successful in this course depends on the individual student’s preparation. As all topics included in the program should be discussed in the individual assignment, I would strongly encourage you to attend all lectures and to read all the articles on the reading list (at least the compulsory readings, but preferably also the recommended readings).
Attending lectures is thus some advice, but it is not compulsory. However, you are NOT allowed to miss:

column1: This course is designed to provide students with advanced skills on the enforcement of law in the field of regulation of markets. In particular, students learn how to use economic arguments and economic evidence in real-life cases in courts and/or regulatory agencies. The course is organized in a moot court format. Students must take the role of plaintiffs, defendants, regulators or regulatees. They are supposed to base their arguments and decisions, both orally and in writing, on economic analysis of law. The topics, which are reviewed yearly, include inter alia competition law, product liability, mergers and acquisitions, financial and consumer law.
This course is open for EMLE students only.

column1: <body>The master’s thesis is the major project in the entire programme. With their master's thesis, students demonstrate that they are able to contribute to academic and sophisticated professional debates on a specific subject. Each student that achieved satisfactory results in his/her coursework will be appointed with a supervisor. Supervisors will provide personal advice on various occasions to ensure that students can make reliable progress. The master's thesis will fulfil the following criteria:

column2: • it is based on a clearly formulated research question;
• it relates to theories and methodologies of the discipline, or theories and methodologies relevant to the specific theme;
• the selected theories and methodologies are discussed and justified in the thesis with respect to the formulation of the problem;
• previous research concerning the chosen theme are summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to the original aspects of the thesis;
• the academic literature as well as all other information and data used are systematically presented and related to the main theme of the thesis;
• the thesis contains a clear, succinctly written conclusion;
• the thesis contains an introduction, various chapters in which theory, method and the findings are discussed, a conclusion, a bibliography and (possibly) appendices;
• the literature, sources and other information and data are accurately referenced;
• the thesis is written in polished, accurate English;
• the main text of the thesis does not far exceed 20.000 words.

column1: Het schrijven van de master thesis staat centraal tijdens de masteropleiding. In de master thesis laten studenten zien dat zij op basis van eigen, oorspronkelijk onderzoek een bijdrage kunnen leveren aan het wetenschappelijke debat over een bepaald onderwerp uit het eigen vakgebied.
Overige eisen die worden gesteld aan de master thesis zijn:
• het onderzoek is gebaseerd op een helder geformuleerde probleemstelling en daaruit afgeleide
• het onderzoek is gestoeld op theorieën en methoden uit het vakgebied, dan wel theorieën en methoden die voor dit specifieke onderwerp relevant zijn;
• deze theorieën en methoden worden in de thesis besproken en beargumenteerd in relatie tot de probleemstelling;
• eerder onderzoek rond het gekozen onderwerp wordt aangegeven, samengevat en besproken voorzover relevant voor het eigen onderzoek;
• gebruikte literatuur, primaire en secundaire bronnen, overige gegevens en data worden systematisch gepresenteerd en aan elkaar gerelateerd;
• de thesis bestaat uit een inleiding, diverse hoofdstukken waarin de bevindingen worden besproken, conclusie, literatuurlijst en (eventueel) bijlagen;
• het onderzoek mondt uit in een heldere, bondig geschreven conclusie;
• literatuur, bronnen en overige gegevens en data worden nauwkeurig opgegeven in voetnoten,
• de thesis is geschreven in verzorgd en accuraat Nederlands of Engels;
• de thesis kent een omvang van 20.000 woorden (+/- 10 %), exclusief titelblad, inhoudsopgave,

Overige eisen die  worden gesteld aan de  master thesis zijn:

column1: voorzover  relevant voor  het eigen onderzoek;

<body>Writing a master's thesis is the central feature of the research master's programme. The master's thesis enables students, based on their own original research, to demonstrate their abilities to contribute to the academic debate of a specific subject in their field of study. The following are additional requirements that the master's thesis must satisfy:

column2: • the research will based on a clearly formulated problem and subsequent research questions;
• the research will be based on theories and methodologies relevant to the field of study and the specific theme;
• the theories and methodologies will be discussed and argued in the thesis with respect to the formulation of the problem;
• previous research concerning the chosen theme will be indicated, summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to one's own research;
• the literature used, primary and secondary sources, other information and data will be systematically presented and interrelated;
• the research will result in a clear, succinctly written conclusion.

column1: The master's thesis should have the format of an article for an international peer-reviewed academic journal. As such it should meet the following requirements:

column2: • the article will contain a clearly stated research problem and research question(s); a description of the scientific/ background and relevance of the research question(s); an outline of the methods of data collection and analysis; a presentation and discussion of the findings, and a conclusion highlighting the scientific relevance of the findings and how these relate to the existent literature on the topic;
• the literature, sources and other information and data will be accurately listed in footnotes and the references, and, if necessary, in separate appendices;
• the article will be preceded by an abstract (200-400 words) and five key words;
• the article accords with the established formats of the relevant journal(s) within the disciplinary and thematic field that fits the research topic.
• the article will be written in polished, accurate English;
• the article will consist of a maximum of 10.000 words, excluding footnotes and references, tables and figures, abstract and key words.

column1: Students have developed the knowlegde and skills to:​

column2: • Formulate an original and relevant scholarly problem in his or her field of study
• Draw up an appropriate research proposal, including a positioning of the thesis in currently scholarly discussion, a well-argued research strategy, and time plan
• Organize the research set-up (empirical and/or fieldwork research)
• Use current social-scientific methods and techniques to collect and analyze the required information and data
• Report on the results/findings in a coherent and reflexive way
• Evaluate the conclusions and choices made during the research process
• Write an academic article in English, to be submitted for publication to an international peer-reviewed academic journal

column1: In this course, students decide on the topic and shape the outlines of their Master Thesis – an original and autonomously conducted academic study. Throughout, the emphasis is on the relationship between the research question, theory, data and analysis, and how to integrate these elements into a  well-structured research design. During the ‘thesis market’ the available supervisors of the programme will suggest themes and topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers, but may also consist of questions/requests for research that specific cultural organisations might have. After that, students will come up with a topic of their interest. They will then develop this into a suitable, feasible and well-argued research proposal, which will be the basis of the work on the actual Master Thesis.

This course consists of two components. On the one hand, there is a personal trajectory in which students will develop a plan for their Master Thesis in the form of a research proposal. They will do so through consecutive assignments, where there is room for trial-and-error and individual feedback is provided in the various steps. On the other hand, regular meetings serve as collective checkpoints to streamline the process. In doing so, ample attention is paid to content-related matters and designing a suitable method, as well as the time planning and formal criteria, to make sure that the Master Thesis (and the Master Thesis proposal) is in line with the programme’s requirements. Therefore, we will consider (and in some cases freshen up) topics such as conceptualizing, searching for and integrating literature, various methodologies, and academic writing.

column1: Students investing fully in this course will be able to write a clear, well-structured and feasible research proposal for their Master Thesis, including an introduction (research question and relevance), a literature review/theoretical framework and a data and methods section. In the process students will identify a topic, formulate a clear research question, search for, find and select relevant literature, operationalize theoretical concepts and come up with a suitable method of research.

column1: We will study selected aspects of methodology (what is research?) and empirical research methods (how do we collect and analyze data?). ​During the course, we will discuss previous empirical findings and methodological tools available in our field. Students will have the chance to develop a research proposal to understand the relationship between the problem statement, the analysis of the data, and the concluding answer to the research question. The course will provide the discussion space to explore setting up a research project which, eventually, can become the actual MA thesis. At the end of the course, the student is expected to be able to apply the empirical methods of the discipline to develop a coherent and feasible research proposal.

column1: First, we will explain all the content-related and formal criteria the Master Thesis and master thesis proposal have to fulfill as well as the time planning. Second, during the ‘thesis market’ the lecturers of the programme will present potential thesis topics which lie on the intersections between tourism, culture and society that students can – but do not have to – choose as their Master Thesis topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers or consist of questions specific cultural organisations might have. Third, we will elaborate on turning a relevant and feasible topic into a research question. During the last two meetings, students will start writing their master thesis proposal. Fourth, students learn to search, find and select relevant literature and make efficient use of various digital search tools. The emphasis, however, will be on the relationship between the research question, theory, data and analysis, and how to integrate these elements into a well-structured and logical research design. Fifth, students will receive tips and tricks and practice their writing skills and learn to monitor and optimize the writing process.

This includes an introduction (research question and relevance), a theoretical framework and a data and methods section. In the process students will be able to identify a topic, formulate a concise research question, search, find and select relevant literature, operationalize theoretical concepts and come up with a suitable methodology.

column1: In order to complete the HEPL master, with specialisation Health Economics, students are required to write a scientific Master thesis on a topic that is related to one of the subjects covered in the HE Master. The combined workload of the Thesis Plan and Thesis is 16 ECTS (or 448 hours) and thus constitutes a major part of the curriculum. Students write their Master thesis under supervision of a member of the HEPL or ESE staff. The evaluation of the thesis and defence for the final grade is conducted by the student's thesis reading committee, which includes the supervisor and one co-evaluator. The co-evaluator must be someone from the ESHPM or ESE staff.
More information regarding the HE thesis, the graduation procedure, and a link to the course book can be found at https://my.eur.nl/en/ese/master/master-thesis

column1: <body>First, we will explain all the content-related and formal criteria the Master Thesis and master thesis proposal have to fulfil as well as the time planning. Second, during the ‘thesis market’ the lecturers of the programme will present potential thesis topics which lie on the intersections between tourism, culture and society that students can – but do not have to – choose as their Master Thesis topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers or consist of questions specific cultural organisations might have. Third, we will elaborate on turning a relevant and feasible topic into a research question. During the last two meetings, students will start writing their master thesis proposal. Fourth, students learn to search, find and select relevant literature and make efficient use of various digital search tools. The emphasis, however, will be on the relationship between the research question, theory, data and analysis, and how to integrate these elements into a well-structured and logical research design. Fifth, students will receive tips and tricks and practice their writing skills and learn to monitor and optimize the writing process.</body>

column1: Students need to write a MSc thesis on a behavioural economics topic. The thesis is an individual assignment about a subject from your Master's specialisation. The student can either choose a topic and supervisor from a list, or propose their own research topic.
In November, a topic pitch event is organized. Students can get to know the available supervisors and the topics they are interested in.
In December, students submit their topic and supervisor preferences.
In January, the matching of students and their supervisors is announced.
In January and February, students are developing their research question and writing their research proposal.
Between March and July, the student is conducting the research and writing the thesis.
More information about thesis subjects, thesis supervisors and the writing process can be found on the Behavioural Economics Master Thesis page on Canvas.
The final grade is based on the thesis and defence presentation. In order to defend the thesis, the research proposal has to be approved and uploaded in Sin Online.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students obtain in-depth knowledge about a topic of their choice. The topic is related to behavioral economics and may be related to their track.
• Students learn how to write a research proposal.
• Students obtain knowledge about the ethical aspects of conducting scientific research.
• Students learn how to conduct a scientific literature review.
• Students learn to formulate a research question and hypotheses.
• Students learn to set up an experiment and/or gather data (theoretical theses excluded).
• Students learn to test their hypotheses using a variety of statistical analysis methods (theoretical theses excluded).
• Students learn to critically assess their own work by writing a discussion and limitations section.
• Students learn how to construct a reference list following academic rules (e.g., APA).
• Students learn how to deal with feedback in a professional manner.
• Students learn giving academic presentations.
• Students learn to plan and complete a complicated long-term (6-month) project, comprised of different stages and tasks.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which methods and techniques of scientific research in the field of data science and marketing can be applied to their own research topic.
• Students are able to: formulate a clear research question based on relevant academic concepts and theories, and legitimized by up-to-date academic or social developments.
• The student can select the correct data and appropriate analysis technique to answer the research question.
• The student shows he can work independently.

• Students are able to: analyze and interpret data in an accurate, reliable, comprehensive and verifiable way and to formulate conclusions which sufficiently take into account presuppositions, basic principles and the limitations/opportunities of the selected methodology.
• Students are able to: link their findings to existing (academic) literature on the topic. This applies to findings relating to both the methods used and the obtained management implications.

• Students are able to: report on research findings in a logical and consistent way and give a clear oral explanation of the research project as well as to answer critical questions about the research in a convincing manner.

column1: Your thesis is the ‘masterpiece’ of your master’s degree in Sociology. The master’s thesis is an empirical study demonstrating that you have all the necessary competences to independently formulate sociologically relevant research questions, to select and apply suitable theoretical frameworks and methodological approaches consistent with the disciplinary and legal norms relating to privacy and ethics, and to communicate your work in a scientific and professional manner.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>In the process of writing your master’s thesis proposal, conducting the research necessary to answer your research question(s), and reporting on the study conducted in your master’s thesis, you will learn:

column2: • To formulate a suitable and sociologically relevant problem statement;
• To provide an overview of the extant literature in the chosen research subfield, resulting in a detailed and specific research question(s);
• To differentiate between descriptive and explanatory research questions;
• To use sociological theory and empirical findings to develop hypotheses and/or sub-questions, which constitute the basis for your theoretical framework;
• To create an appropriate research design to answer your research question(s);
• To assess the feasibility of your research design;
• To demonstrate and document the proper, careful consideration of the ethics and privacy implications of your study;
• To reliably operationalize the core concepts of your study;
• To independently conduct empirical research using secondary or primary (self-collected) data, using suitable analytical methods and techniques;
• To discuss the theoretical and empirical value of your study and evaluate your study’s sociological and societal relevance;

column1: The final thesis takes the form of an individual research project. The topic can be chosen by the student, but it needs to be related to one or more of the IMP courses. The thesis must  have an international dimension, focusing for instance on an international organization or  involving  a cross-national comparison. Note that an internship is not part of our program.

At the start of block 3, students will be matched with a supervisor, who will very often be one of the lecturers that taught the mandatory courses of this master program. This is coordinated by the IMP program directors and depends on the expertise and thesis-load of potential supervisors. After the manuscript has been approved by the supervisor, he or she will involve a second reader. When both approve the research project and all requirements of the IMP master have been satisfied, the thesis will be defended in front of the delegated examination board.</body>

column1: Het vak Masterclasses wordt verzorgd door de partners die verbonden zijn aan Toga aan de Maas. Er wordt gewerkt met drie lijnen binnen het vak Masterclasses: (i) Togavaardigheden, (ii) Verdieping/inhoudelijk en (iii) Soft skills. Binnen de lijn Togavaardigheden leren de studenten een juridische procedure te doorlopen. Onder andere de volgende onderwerpen komen hier aan bod: het eerste contact met cliënten, het analyseren van een dossier en procesadvies, schriftelijke stukken opstellen, processtrategie, comparitie van partijen en pleiten, vonnis schrijven, hoger beroep en cassatie. Ook alternatieve geschilbeslechting komt binnen deze lijn aan bod. Binnen de lijn Verdieping/inhoudelijk worden belangrijke juridische leerstukken en actuele onderwerpen besproken. Tot slot, staat de lijn Soft skills in het teken van de persoonlijke ontwikkeling van studenten, met onderwerpen als legal English, personal branding, presenteren/pitchen, onderhandelen en stress management. De diverse masterclasses vinden plaats bij de partnerkantoren, bestaande uit advocatenkantoren, het Openbaar Ministerie en de rechtspraak.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• De student kan zelfstandig een juridisch vraagstuk oplossen, bijbehorend onderzoek verrichten (in de papieren en digitale bronnen zelfstandig gevonden informatie op correcte wijze analyseren en beoordelen om deze vervolgens toe te passen en te verwerken) en daarvan verslag doen.
• De student kan in samenwerking oplossingen aandragen voor een juridisch complex probleem en kan binnen die samenwerking een eigen visie vormen en die motiveren.
• De student kan rekening houden met de invloed van verschillende rechtsgebieden en het vraagstuk in bredere context plaatsen.

• De student beheerst zowel de schriftelijke als de mondelinge togavaardigheden, dus kan onder andere (juridische) adviezen, memoranda, brieven en processtukken schrijven, alsook cliëntgesprekken voeren, getuigenverhoren afnemen, onderhandelen en pleidooi houden.

• De student is op de hoogte van actualiteiten in verschillende rechtsgebieden en begrijpt de maatschappelijke en juridische relevantie van de betreffende actualiteit in relatie tot de wereld van het recht.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114042,2023,Masterclass actualiteiten gezondheidsrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr.dr. AP den Exter', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit vak wordt het onderwijs primair verzorgd door gerenommeerde juristen (advocaten, ziekenhuisjuristen, etc.) werkzaam in de praktijk van het gezondheidsrecht. Zij laten de studenten kennismaken met actuele ontwikkelingen op de verschillende deelterreinen van dit rechtsgebied: het zorgverleningsrecht, het zorgverzekeringsrecht en het zorginkooprecht. Van de studenten wordt gevraagd hun eerder opgedane kennis van deze deelgebieden van het gezondheidsrecht toe te passen op actuele vraagstukken. De studenten krijgen van de gastdocenten casuïstiek voorgelegd, die zij moeten behandelen in wekelijks in te leveren werkstukken. De rechtsvragen die de studenten krijgen voorgelegd, zijn ontleend aan die van de rechtspraktijk van de gastdocenten. Het onderwijs vindt deels plaats ten kantore van de praktijkjuristen.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• De student heeft kennisgemaakt met de praktijk van het gezondheidsrecht en de laatste ontwikkelingen op alle deelterreinen van dit rechtsgebied. Hij heeft weet van de relevante rechtspraak en nieuwe ontwikkelingen op deze terreinen en is in staat om deze ontwikkelingen te kunnen plaatsen en op hun relevantie te kunnen beoordelen.

• De student beschikt over juridische en algemene academische vaardigheden, waarbij kennis van het gezondheidsrecht, inzicht en probleemoplossende vermogens kunnen worden toegepast in nieuwe of onbekende omstandigheden binnen de bredere (of multidisciplinaire) context van dit rechtsgebied.
• Dit betekent dat de student wet- en regelgeving op casuïstiek kan toepassen en een logisch antwoord kan formuleren op de rechtsvragen bij een casus.
• De student op basis van een actuele casus de rechtsvraag kan formuleren;
• De student geeft bij het doen van de praktijkopdrachten blijk van creativiteit en zelfstandigheid.
• De student durft een eigen mening te uiten tijdens colleges, door middel van het doen van onderbouwde uitspraken met betrekking tot de behandelde stof.

column1: Peter Daszak is a British zoologist, consultant and public expert on disease ecology, in particular on zoonosis. Dr. Daszak’s research has been instrumental in identifying and predicting the origins and impact of emerging diseases across the globe. This includes identifying the bat origin of SARS, the drivers of Nipah virus emergence, publishing the first global emerging disease ‘hotspots’ map, discovering SADS coronavirus, designing a strategy to identify the number of unknown viruses in wildlife, launching the Global Virome Project, identifying the first case of a species extinction due to disease, and discovering the disease chytridiomycosis as the cause global amphibian declines. He is one of the founders of the field of Conservation Medicine and has been instrumental in the growth of EcoHealth, One Health, and now Planetary Health.

A fundamental part of the Dr. Daszak’s work on disease ecology is directed by the conviction that disease outbreaks are not just predictable, but preventable. This approach is informed by a perspective on emerging infectious disease research that sees problems of human and animal disease as intimately linked – exacerbated by ecological change. With this in mind, he led the researcher that produced the first ever global emerging disease ‘hotspots’ map to determine where in the world viruses with pandemic potential are most likely to emerge, and developed a strategy to identify just how many of those viruses currently exist.
Self-study assignments, including reading articles and formulate 2 questions.

Participants who submit assignments after the deadline will be excluded from the course. Please note that the cancellation policy will apply.

You will receive all details for the pre-assignment one week prior to the start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location and the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.

column1: *the program may be subject to change.
Pre-assignment – The assignment is mandatory for this course
Preparation assignment: reading articles and formulate 2 questions.
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

column1: De scriptie is een individueel werkstuk over een onderwerp uit je Masterprogramma. Meer informatie over scriptieonderwerpen, scriptiebegeleiders en het schrijfproces is te vinden op de Thesis Hub Master Fiscale Economie.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Studenten leren zelfstandig verdiepende kennis op te doen over een fiscaal of fiscaal-economisch onderwerp en over dat onderwerp een onderzoek doen opzetten en zelfstandig doen uitvoeren, d.w.z. van het opstellen van een onderzoeksvraag tot het afronden van het onderzoeksverslag.
• Studenten leren een relevante onderzoeksvraag te formuleren op het terrein van het zelfgekozen fiscale of fiscaal-economische onderwerp.

• Studenten leren over hun onderzoek in overeenstemming met de geldende academische standaarden correct en bondig op logische en consistente wijze schriftelijk verslag te doen en dit vervolgens mondeling overtuigend te presenteren en te verdedigen.
